The Enterprise Transcripts - Sleeping Dogs
Sleeping
Dogs
 Original Airdate: 30 Jan, 2002
  [Armoury]
 (A phase pistol is loaded, and a target projector is
set up.)
REED: You have a ten second firing window. Ready?
HOSHI: Ready.
REED: Go. (He pushes a button on PADD, the 3D target starts moving around
and Hoshi fires a lot of shots in its direction.) REED: Time.
HOSHI: Any better?
REED: Your hit to miss ratio is still below fifty percent. If those had
been live rounds, you'd have blown out two or three bulkheads.
HOSHI: I never had this much trouble with the EM-33.
REED: This is an entirely new weapon. Unlike the EM-33 you don't have
to compensate for particle drift. Just point straight at the target,
and try and keep your shoulders relaxed. It's hard to aim accurately
when you're tense. Ahem.
HOSHI: You all right?
REED: Yeah, fine. You'll get the hang of it. Let's try for twenty
seconds this time.
(The engine sound changes.)
HOSHI: I thought we were staying at warp for the next few days. (Reed checks the monitor.)
REED: We're approaching a gas giant. Class nine.
HOSHI: So much for target practice.
REED: We'll pick it up tomorrow.
 [Bridge]
 T'POL: The probe's entered the outer atmosphere. (The viewscreen is fuzzy orange.)
ARCHER: Can we clean up the signal?
HOSHI: I'm trying, sir. There's a lot of EM interference. It sounds
very strange.
T'POL: Intense magnetic fields often create unique waveforms.
ARCHER: Let's hear them. (Electronic Jupiter-type music,)
TRAVIS: Siren calls. That's what we called them when I was a kid. My
dad would put them through the speakers whenever we flew by a gas
giant. It gave me nightmares sometimes. (Hoshi stops the sounds.)
T'POL: Other than keeping Ensign Mayweather up at night, I'm not sure
what we expect to accomplish here. There are four gas giants in your
own solar system.
ARCHER: None of them are class nine. I think this one's worth a closer
look.
T'POL: I'm reading an anomalous power signature in the lower
atmosphere, and several biosigns.
ARCHER: Get the probe closer.
TRAVIS: Aye, sir. (Through the murk, a ship comes into view.)
 [Sickbay]
(Reed sneezing into a tissue.)  REED: We can travel
faster than the speed of light. You'd think we could find a cure for
the common cold.
PHLOX: You should be grateful. A human cold is so mild. I once had a
patient with the Kamaraazite flu. He sneezed so violently he nearly
regurgitated his pineal gland.
REED: I don't see how I could actually catch a cold on a hermetically
sealed starship.
PHLOX: Oh, you may have picked up the virus from a piece of equipment.
It could have been lurking inside a sealed container.
REED: I did open a case of plasma coolant.
PHLOX: Whoever packed that case was probably nursing a cold.
REED: But that was back in Spacedock five months ago.
PHLOX: You underestimate the tenacity of a virus, Lieutenant. It can
lay dormant for months, adapt to whatever environment it finds itself
in. This should ease the symptoms. (Phlox gives Reed a hypospray.) PHLOX: But the only cure
I know of involves bed rest.
REED: No, that'll have to wait. The Captain wants me on the team
investigating that shipwreck.
PHLOX: Well, you won't be contagious inside an environment suit. Just
try not to sneeze in your helmet.
REED: I'll do my best.
 [Ready room]
 ARCHER: Come in. Hoshi.
HOSHI: Do you have a minute, sir?
ARCHER: Of course. What's on your mind?
HOSHI: That shipwreck. We have no idea what type of life forms we'll
find on that alien vessel, and there's a lot of interference in the
atmosphere. Are you sure the away team won't need a translator?
ARCHER: They have their UTs, and we'll try to keep an open comlink.
HOSHI: What about the language on the control panels, the hatches? They
might need someone to help them find their way around.
ARCHER: Are you trying to tell me something?
HOSHI: I realise that I haven't always been the first one in line to
volunteer for this type of mission, but I want you to know that I am
prepared to go. Took a while, but I think I finally got my space legs.
ARCHER: I never doubted that you'd find them. Your timing couldn't be
better. T'Pol just asked me to assign you to the team. You'd better get
to the launch bay before they leave without you.
HOSHI: Aye, sir.
 [Locker room]
 T'POL: I thought you were acquainted with the
environmental suit.
HOSHI: I am. I'm just brushing up on the backup systems. I wouldn't
want the emergency oxygen to fail during a hull breach.
REED: Trust me, Ensign. If there's a hull breach the pressure will
crush you to something about this big. (He holds up a clenched fist.)
T'POL: I requested you for your skills as a translator, but if you're
uncomfortable.
HOSHI: I'm perfectly comfortable. I used to find the suits a little
claustrophobic, but I'm getting used to them. I'll see you in the
shuttlepod.
 [Shuttlepod]
(Reed is doing the flying.)  REED: It's one hundred
kilometres below us, still descending.
T'POL: Gravity's pulling it deeper into the atmosphere. At their
current altitude the pressure is fifteen thousand gsc.
REED: That's well within our hull tolerance.
T'POL: For the moment. But at the rate that vessel is sinking, we'll
have an hour at most.
HOSHI: You sound uncomfortable, Sub-Commander.
T'POL: I'm merely stating facts.
REED: We'll be on our way back well before we're in any danger. I for
one have no interest in imploding a valuable shuttlepod.
HOSHI: Or three valuable officers. (The pod shakes.)
T'POL: We've entered an eddy of liquid helium. We're clear.
HOSHI: That wasn't so bad.
T'POL: One hundred metres.
HOSHI: Is that a hatch on the port side?
REED: I see it.
T'POL: Fifty metres. Forty.
HOSHI: What's that?
REED: It's just the proximity alarm.
T'POL: Twenty metres. Ten. Engaging docking interface.
 [Alien ship]
 T'POL: Nitrogen-oxygen atmosphere. Carbon dioxide
levels are high, but nothing's toxic. It's breathable.
HOSHI: You first. (Reed opens his helmet and nods, T'Pol opens hers and
nearly gags.) HOSHI: Perhaps we should leave the helmets on.
REED: What is it?
HOSHI: (coughing) You can't smell that?
REED: No. This damn cold.
HOSHI: Count your blessings. (They walk along the corridor.) HOSHI: You two might
want to take a look at this. (There are symbols on a bulkhead.) HOSHI: It says deck two,
red sector.
REED: What language?
HOSHI: Klingon. (All draw their phase pistols.) HOSHI: I thought you knew
Klingon ships. Why didn't you recognise this one from the outside?
T'POL: There are many classes of ships. I'm not familiar with all of
them.
REED: So I'm assuming you don't know how many Klingons are on board.
T'POL: I'm reading three biosigns. That way. All very weak.
HOSHI: How weak?
 [Klingon bridge]
 T'POL: They're still alive. We should leave before
they regain consciousness.
REED: And what if they don't? The atmosphere's going to crush this ship
like an eggshell pretty soon.
HOSHI: Shouldn't we try to help them?
T'POL: They don't want our help.
HOSHI: How do you know?
T'POL: They're Klingons. To die at their post assures them a path to
the afterlife. If we rescue them, they'd be dishonoured.
REED: Well, I for one don't intend to just fly off and let these people
die, honourable deaths or not.
T'POL: Your compassion is admirable but misguided. If they awake and
find us on their ship, they'll kill us. (In the Klingon galley, there are carcasses hanging from butcher's hooks, some
green stuff in bowls. A woman walks out of a storage area,)
 [Klingon bridge]
 ARCHER [OC]: How many are there?
T'POL: Three on the bridge, but I'm detecting at least nine more
biosigns on board.
ARCHER [OC]: You can't tell what happened to them?
 [Bridge]
 T'POL [OC]: I'm detecting residual amounts of an
carbon dioxide based neurotoxin, but it seems to have dissipated.
There's not enough to affect us.
ARCHER: Stand by. How long is the pod's hull going to hold up?
TUCKER: At their present rate of descent, half hour, give or take.
ARCHER: T'Pol.
T'POL [OC]: Yes, Captain.
ARCHER: You've got twenty minutes to see if you can do anything for
that crew, then I want you out of there.
 [Klingon bridge]
 ARCHER [OC]: Understood?
T'POL: I don't believe there's anything we can do in twenty minutes. I
suggest we leave now.
ARCHER [OC]: You have a margin of safety. (He crackles out.)
T'POL: Captain? T'Pol to Enterprise.
 [Klingon corridor]
 (The Klingon woman moves towards the voices.)
REED [OC]: Damn interference.
T'POL [OC]: Or we've dropped out of comm. range.
HOSHI [OC]: We still have twenty minutes.
T'POL [OC]: It doesn't make sense to place ourselves at risk when
they'd rather die.
REED [OC]: There must be something we can do. Maybe they have a
distress beacon we can activate.
 [Klingon bridge]
 (The woman sees them then retreats.)
T'POL: I doubt you'll find one. Klingons don't call for help.
HOSHI: What if we carry some of them into the pod? We could save three
or four.
T'POL: And if they wake up on the trip back to Enterprise? (The sound of a
bulkhead closing. Reed pulls his pistol and goes to investigate. The woman
jumps him and escapes.)
 [Klingon Corridor]
 HOSHI: What's that?
T'POL: It's our shuttlepod taking off.
 [Bridge]
 TUCKER: Try it now.
ARCHER: Archer to T'Pol. What's your status?
TUCKER: They're back in comm. range. (Travis sees the shuttlepod leaving the gas giant.)
TRAVIS:  Captain.
ARCHER: Shuttlepod One, respond.
TRAVIS: Sir, they're heading into open space.
TUCKER: I'm picking up something.
BU'KAH [OC]: Duj-to! Chak wa kah Deesh paklah! kah Deesh paklah!
ARCHER: Sounds like Klingon.
TUCKER: I'll try to tie in the UT.
BU'KAH [OC]: Chak wa kah Deesh paklah! kah Deesh paklah! 'kiv Duj in
range. Respond. We've been attacked by an unknown ship designation
Enterprise NX-01. Any warships in range, respond.
ARCHER: Set a pursuit course.
TRAVIS: Aye, sir.
ARCHER: Bring the grappler online.
(The launcher lowers, two lines are fired and latch onto the
shuttlepod.)
TUCKER: We've got it.
ARCHER: Bridge to Security. Send a team to launch bay one. Trip. The
bridge is yours, Travis.
TRAVIS: Yes, sir.
 [Launch bay]
 (Archer and Trip enter cautiously, with phase
pistols drawn, two security guards right behind them. The pod hatch is
open, and Bu'kaH jumps the guard who goes to look inside. It takes stun
shots from both Archer and Trip to knock her out.)
ARCHER: Everybody all right? (Trip nods as the guards get up again.)
ARCHER: Archer to the Bridge.
TRAVIS [OC]: Mayweather.
ARCHER: Have you still got a fix on the shipwreck?
TRAVIS [OC]: Yes, sir.
ARCHER: Transfer the coordinates to the launch bay. I'm going back for
the boarding party.
TRAVIS [OC]: Sir, the alien ship sunk another two thousand metres. It's
below the shuttle's safety limits.
ARCHER: Then polarise the hull plating. We'll take Enterprise down.
 [Klingon Bridge]
 REED: There's got to be some way off this ship.
HOSHI: What about escape pods?
REED: I don't know about the structural integrity of Klingon escape
pods. My guess is we're better off in here.
T'POL: It's irrelevant, Lieutenant. Klingons don't use escape pods. It
would be considered an act of cowardice to abandon ship.
HOSHI: Maybe we can use their comm. system to contact Enterprise.
T'POL: I doubt their comm. will penetrate the EM field any better than
our own. If we can access their helm controls we might be able to put
this vessel into a stable orbit.
REED: I haven't had much experience at piloting Klingon ships.
T'POL: We have no other choice. (The hull groans under the pressure.)
T'POL: Start translating those consoles. Look for anything marked propulsion,
helm, navigation.
HOSHI: I'll try, but reading Klingon is a lot different than speaking
it.
REED: We could always try waking one of them to help us.
HOSHI: All right. (reads a monitor screen) Kolat chack tabak. Plasma
containment, maybe.
T'POL: You're certain?
HOSHI: Containment. I'm certain. (She moves to the next screen.) HOSHI: Pu'DaH dak cha.
Something they call photon torpedoes.
REED: Photon torpedoes? I've never heard of anything like that. What
else?
HOSHI: Well, this all looks like weapons systems. Torpedoes, tactical
sensors, disruptor arrays.
T'POL: (another screen) What about this one?
HOSHI: I recognise pressure. Ka'tahl. That can mean wall or barrier.
T'POL: Or hull?
HOSHI: Maybe.
REED: If I'm reading this correctly we've got a few hours at most. The
hull integrity's failing.
T'POL: Then we'd better hurry. This appears to be the helm station.
HOSHI: I think you're right. Quee nagah. Impulse drive.
REED: Good work, Hoshi. (Reed tries to use the controls, but alarms sound
instead and text scrolls on a screen.) REED: Hoshi?
HOSHI: It says the pressure's failing in the J'khat bah. Fusion
manifold. Do you know what that means?
REED: To quote our very own Mister Tucker, that means we're dead in the
water.
ARCHER [OC]: Archer to boarding party. Come in.
HOSHI: We read you, Captain.
 [Bridge]
 ARCHER: How are you holding up?
HOSHI [OC]: We're doing okay, sir. It's nice to hear your voice.
ARCHER: What's your status?
 [Klingon Bridge]
 T'POL: We've been attempting to restart their
engines, but they appear to be offline.
ARCHER [OC]: Don't worry about it. We're coming to get you.
 [Bridge]
 ARCHER: Travis, how much farther?
TRAVIS: Ten thousand metres, but I'm having a hard time getting a fix
on them. Too much interference.
ARCHER: Is our probe still working?
TUCKER: Barely.
ARCHER: Try using it to triangulate their position.
(But we see the probe implode.)
TUCKER: The probe's gone. (The hull groans.)
TRAVIS: Sir, external pressure's at maximum.
ARCHER: I'm afraid we've got a little hitch in our rescue plan. (Big
metallic groans.)
TRAVIS: The hull plating's failing.
ARCHER: We'll be back for you as soon as we can.
 [Klingon Bridge]
 ARCHER [OC]: In the meantime, just sit tight.
(He dissolves into static.)
HOSHI: Captain, you're breaking up. Captain?
 [Sickbay]
(The Klingon woman is struggling against biobed restraints.)
 BU'KAH: Release me. Cowards! Let me die on my feet.
PHLOX: T'Pol was right. There's a neurotoxin in her bloodstream.
Untreated, it could kill her within a day or two.
ARCHER: Can you do anything?
PHLOX: I'm working on it.
TUCKER: T'Pol said the Klingons were unconscious. Why is this one so
lively?
PHLOX: She's showing the effects of hypothermia. My guess is she took
refuge in a low temperature environment aboard her ship. The cold would
have delayed the effects of the toxin.
BU'KAH: I demand to speak to your Captain.
TUCKER: You know, I read if they sense a leader's weak, they'll try to
kill him and take command.
ARCHER: I'm the Captain.
BU'KAH: I've never seen your kind before but you have made an enemy of
the Klingon Empire.
ARCHER: From what I've noticed, that's not hard to do. You stranded
three of my people down there.
BU'KAH: You raided my vessel, infected my crew.
ARCHER: We didn't infect anyone. We boarded your ship to try and help.
BU'KAH: Liar.
ARCHER: Look, I don't know what happened to your crew but we had
nothing to do with it. Now your vessel is sinking deeper into the
atmosphere and unless we do something, it'll be destroyed.
BU'KAH: Better that than let it fall into your hands.
ARCHER: I've got three very capable people on your ship. Let them help.
If you tell them how to get the engines running, they can fly it out of
there.
BU'KAH: And fly it where? Back to your world to steal our secrets?
ARCHER: No.
BU'KAH: When our Birds of Prey arrive, your ship will be destroyed.
ARCHER: (to Trip, leaving) Remind me to stop trying to help people.
 [Situation room]
 TRAVIS: I found these schematics in the Vulcan
database. It's a Raptor Class scout vessel.
ARCHER: How long will it last down there?
TRAVIS: Its hull's at least twice as thick as ours, reinforced with
some kind of coherent molecular alloy.
TUCKER: Yeah, it's a tough little ship but it can't hold up under that
pressure forever. What if we use duratanium braces to reinforce a
shuttlepod? It won't look pretty but, it might hold up long enough for
us to get our people out.
TRAVIS: Our only other option is for T'Pol and Malcolm to fix a
broken-down Klingon ship and fly it out themselves.
ARCHER: I don't think we're going to get any help from our guest in
Sickbay. Get started on those braces. (Trip leaves.) ARCHER: Keep an eye out for
any Klingon ships coming this way.
TRAVIS: Aye, sir.
 [Klingon Bridge]
 (The three have removed their outer suits and are
down to blue long-johns.)
REED: The one time we need our Chief Engineer is the one time we leave
him behind.
HOSHI: Come look at this. (She gets a recording playing on a screen in
front of the captain's chair.)
KLINGON [on monitor]: OonoS Thrott! Nej joS mIch ka Xanant 'ach pagh
Q'tahL Class planet. We destroyed their ship, but we've sustained
damage in our port fusion injector. We've descended into the outer
atmosphere of a Q'tahL Class planet to make repairs in case there are
other Xarantine ships in the area. My crew is falling ill and I have
been unable to determine why. If we had died when the Xarantine
attacked our honour would be secure, but to fall victim to some
disease, to be crushed into nothing in the depths of this miserable
planet.
REED: Sounds like we need to find the port fusion injector.
HOSHI: Wait, I saw that somewhere. Here. One deck below us. It's in the
reactor pit.
REED: Reactor pit? Could that be Engineering?
HOSHI: Could be.
 [Klingon Engineering]
 REED: This one?
HOSHI: No. That says something about plasma induction. Here it is. Port
fusion injector. (The panel has a Klingon slumped across it, so Reed
and T'Pol haul him away.)
 [Shuttlepod]
 (Archer is doing some welding.) ARCHER: I think I might have
made a tactical error dealing with the Klingon woman. I asked her for
help. She could see that as a sign of weakness.
TUCKER: You been boning up on your Klingon psychology?
ARCHER: We've run into them three times, and every time they've wanted
to destroy us. I'd love to figure out why. TUCKER: Well, maybe the best
thing is just to steer clear of them.
ARCHER: That may not be so easy. We could use their help right now. If
we can re-establish a comm. signal with T'Pol and the others, the
Klingon woman could probably talk them through the repairs, but she's
got a thousand generations of instinct telling her not to trust me.
TUCKER: Maybe it's time you started thinking like a Klingon.
[deleted scene]
PHLOX [OC]: Sickbay to Captain Archer.
ARCHER: Go ahead.
 [Sickbay]
 PHLOX: You'll be pleased to know I've
developed an antitoxin. There's an interesting wrinkle, though. When
you have a moment I'd like to share it with you.
 [Klingon Engineering]
 (Reed stand up, staggers and burns his hand
against a pipe.)
REED: Argh!
HOSHI: Are you okay?
REED: Yes. I seem to be getting a little light-headed. Must be the
heat.
T'POL: You're dehydrated. You need some water.
HOSHI: I saw a galley on the schematics. Deck four, blue sector. I'll
see what I can find.
T'POL: You shouldn't go alone.
REED: Watch yourselves.
 [Klingon Galley]
(Hoshi picks up a bowl to see what's in
it.)  T'POL: It's called gagh. It's a Klingon delicacy, but only when they're
alive.
HOSHI: They look like worms.
T'POL: They are worms. (Hoshi stirs the ladle in a pot and pulls up an animal skull.) HOSHI: Ugh!
(They hear movement from behind a door, and ready their phase pistols.
T'Pol opens the door to reveal three pigs with lots of spines and
attitude, then shuts it again)
T'POL: Targs. Klingons prefer their food freshly slaughtered. Are you
all right? (Hoshi sits down, scared and upset.)
HOSHI: I promised myself I wouldn't do
this.
T'POL: You're in a dangerous situation in an alien environment. Your
anxiety is understandable.
HOSHI: Don't you mean, for a human?
T'POL: You can't deny your nature.
HOSHI: This may sound strange but I envy you sometimes. I know, another
pesky human emotion, but there are times I wish I could just ignore my
feelings. Bury them the way Vulcans do.
T'POL: Take my hand.
HOSHI: Excuse me? (T'Pol kneels in front of her.)
T'POL:  My hand. Close your eyes. (She puts three
fingers on Hoshi's palm.) T'POL: Think of yourself on a turbulent ocean. You
have the power to control the waves.
HOSHI: Whatever it is you're trying to do, it's not working. (T'Pol shifts her fingers.)
T'POL: Focus. The waves are subsiding. The water
is growing still. You're in control.
HOSHI: That was amazing.
T'POL: When we return to the ship, I'll teach you how to do it on your
own.
HOSHI: Thanks. (The ship jolts.)
T'POL: Lieutenant Reed, report.
 [Klingon Engineering]
 REED: The hull pressure's approaching critical.
This ship's about to be crushed.
(A visual of the outer hull starting to cave in. Reed is drinking.)
REED: It'll work.
T'POL: If you're wrong, you could destroy the ship.
REED: Look, even with Hoshi's help it could take hours just to find the
fusion injector in here. We're out of time.
HOSHI: I say we try the weapons.
T'POL: How do you know you can even access the tactical systems?
REED: If there's one thing on board this ship I ought to be able to
figure out, it's the torpedoes.
 [Ready room]
 TUCKER: I'd like to run one more structural
diagnostic before you launch.
ARCHER: Qapla'.
TUCKER: Beg your pardon?
ARCHER: Success. I decided to take your advice about thinking like a
Klingon. The Vulcan database has about nine hundred pages on them.
TUCKER: Learn anything?
ARCHER: Plenty. They're driven by a warrior mentality. They tend to
view anyone they meet as a potential enemy.
TUCKER: That may explain why our guest is so irritable.
ARCHER: They also have a strong sense of duty. Er, Heh CHo' mruak tah.
Death before dishonour. Finish up that diagnostic. I'll be in Sickbay.
TUCKER: Going to go put your homework to use?
ARCHER: Something like that.
 [Sickbay]
(Phlox gives Bu'kaH a hypo.)  PHLOX: Please relax. If you
strain against the straps you might hurt yourself.
BU'KAH: What's that? Is that what you used against my crew?
ARCHER: Doctor Phlox has developed an antidote to the neurotoxin in
your system.
BU'KAH: Is this how you plan to gain my trust? First poison me, then
miraculously cure me?
ARCHER: Have you had a drink lately?
BU'KAH: What?
ARCHER: The bio-agent that affected you and your crew was consumed,
apparently in alcohol.
PHLOX: Specifically, the toxin was bonded to a molecule unique to
Xarantine ale.
BU'KAH: There was a raid.
ARCHER: Yes? I can understand your not wanting to talk about it, if the
raid went badly for you.
BU'KAH: The Xarantines are no match for us! We attacked their outpost
and took what we wanted.
PHLOX: And that included some Xarantine ale? (She nods)
ARCHER: Did your whole crew drink it?
BU'KAH: The triumph belonged to all.
ARCHER: I'll take that as a yes. It was that ale that infected you, not
us. Think about it. When did your crew start getting sick? Was it right
after the raid? After you celebrated your victory?
BU'KAH: This is a trick.
ARCHER: Is it? How do you feel? Better or worse since the injection? We
can make enough of this for your entire crew, if it's not too late.
What if this isn't a trick? What if we're telling you the truth? You'd
be letting your crew die a very dishonourable death when you could have
saved them. Can you live with that?
 [Klingon Bridge]
 (A photon torpedo has been fired down into the
lower atmosphere.)
HOSHI: One thousand metres. Two thousand. Three thousand. (Detonation,
the ship shakes.) HOSHI: No effect! We're still sinking.
T'POL: The shock wave dissipated before it reached us.
REED: We'll need to detonate one closer next time. (The hull groans)
T'POL: The ship's hull is under enough pressure already. If you
detonate a torpedo too close.
REED: And if I don't? We need to generate a large enough shock wave to
push us into a higher orbit. To do that, the blast has to be big and it
has to be close. (T'Pol nods.) REED: You heard the Sub-Commander. Load two
this time.
 [Shuttlepod]
(Archer is doing the flying.)  ARCHER: Sensor resolution's
dropping off.
BU'KAH: This was your plan? To grope in the darkness and hope to
stumble across my ship?
ARCHER: That's how we found it the first time. (The shuttlepod jolts.)
BU'KAH: What was that?
ARCHER: Weapons fire.
BU'KAH: Where?
ARCHER: Bearing two nine seven mark two six one, down about two
kilometres.
 [Klingon Bridge]
 REED: Did it work?
HOSHI: We've moved up, but only two hundred metres.
REED: That's all? (There is a big bang inside the ship.)
HOSHI: A compartment just collapsed. Deck
three, green sector.
REED: This whole damn ship's coming apart. How many torpedoes do we
have left?
HOSHI: Six.
REED: Load two more.
HOSHI: It won't be enough.
REED: Load the weapons.
HOSHI: We already tried. It didn't work.
REED: Ensign.
T'POL: She's right. We'll never reach a safe altitude climbing a few
hundred metres at a time.
REED: The longer we stand around arguing the more ground we lose.
HOSHI: Fire them all. What if we detonated all the torpedoes at once?
T'POL: We may gain enough altitude, but I doubt we'd make it in one
piece.
HOSHI: I don't know about you but I'm willing to take the chance.
REED: We'll detonate at eight hundred metres.
HOSHI: I was thinking more like five hundred. Look, I didn't come all
this way to get crushed in the atmosphere of some anonymous gas giant.
Loading ports one through six.
REED: Brace yourselves.
HOSHI: Torpedoes armed. (as she presses the launch button, circuits
explode on the bridge)
 [Shuttlepod]
 BU'KAH: What is it?
ARCHER: Another explosion. There's a shock wave this time. Hang on.
(Debris flies up past the shuttlepod, then the ship itself comes into
view.)
 [Klingon Bridge]
(T'Pol answers her communicator.)  T'POL: T'Pol.
ARCHER [OC]: What have you been shooting at?
REED: We used the shock waves to gain some altitude but it's only
temporary. We'll start sinking again unless we can come up with a way
to get this ship out of here.
 [Shuttlepod]
 ARCHER: I brought someone who should be able to
help do just that. We're docking now.
 [Klingon corridor]
 ARCHER: I believe you've all met Officer Bu'kaH.
What's the status of their engines?
T'POL: The Klingon crew made most of the necessary repairs before they
were overcome, but the port fusion injector is still damaged.
BU'KAH: I will tend to my own ship.
ARCHER: I didn't bring you down here just so you could die with your
shipmates. My crew risked their lives to get this ship out of danger. I
don't intend to leave until the job is finished.
 [Bridge]
 TRAVIS: Sir, there are two ships approaching at
high warp. I think they're Klingon.
TUCKER: How long till they get here?
TRAVIS: Sixteen minutes. We're being hailed. It's the Captain.
TUCKER: On screen.
ARCHER [on viewscreen]: This is Klingon Raptor Somraw, hailing
Enterprise. Request permission to disembark four passengers. (Bu'kaH is
in the Captain's chair.)
TUCKER: Well, I don't see why not.
(A little later) TUCKER: I kept your seat warm for you.
ARCHER: Thanks. Get ready to break orbit, Travis. I think we've had
about enough of this place.
TRAVIS: Aye, Captain. It's the Raptor, sir. They're hailing us.
TUCKER: Calling to say thanks?
ARCHER: I doubt it. Put it through. (The Klingon Captain appears on the
viewscreen.) What can I do for you?
KLINGON [on viewscreen]: Prepare to surrender your vessel.
ARCHER: Maybe your engineer neglected to tell you, but we just saved
you and your crew.
KLINGON [on viewscreen]: You violated our ship, accessed our weapons.
ARCHER: It was either that or stand by and watch you get crushed.
KLINGON [on viewscreen]: Disruptors!
TUCKER: They're charging weapons.
ARCHER: You wouldn't last ten seconds in a battle with us. You've got
multiple hull breaches, your shields are down, and from what I'm told
you're fresh out of torpedoes. If I were you, I'd take what little
honour I had left and go home. Fire one shot and I'll blast you right
back to where we found you. (The transmission ends with a snarl.)
TRAVIS: They're moving off.
ARCHER: Get us out of here before their friends show up. (He shakes head.)
 [Decon chamber]
 (The team is relaxing in the UV light, and the comm. unit is beeping.)
REED: Is someone going to get that?
HOSHI: You're closer.
T'POL: T'Pol.
PHLOX [OC]: This is Doctor Phlox. You'll be happy to know that you're
now free of any microbes or parasites. Your captivity in Decon is over.
REED: Are you sure, Doctor? Who knows what was living on that ship?
HOSHI: What if we picked up something your scans can't detect?
PHLOX [OC]: Well, I'm quite sure you didn't. I've run every possible
test.
T'POL: Maybe you should run them again, Doctor. I believe I'm
developing a slight headache.
PHLOX [OC]: Of course, if you insist. I wouldn't want to miss anything.
T'POL: Thank you, Doctor.
REED: That should buy us at least another half an hour.
HOSHI: Oh, I could stay in here all day.
REED: Went to a spa once in Mexico. The most relaxing place I've ever
been, but it doesn't compare to this. Oh, it certainly feels nice to be
clean again.
T'POL: It is pleasant.
HOSHI: Do you smell that?
T'POL: I don't smell anything.
HOSHI: Exactly.

The Enterprise Transcripts - Shadows of P'Jem
Shadows
of P'Jem
 Original Airdate: 6 Feb, 2002
  [Starfleet
headquarters, San Francisco - Forrest's office]
 SOVAL: The loss to the Vulcan people is
incalculable. P'Jem was one of our most revered sanctuaries.
FORREST: Ambassador, we are very sorry for your loss, but with all due
respect the High Command has to take some responsibility. You were
using the monastery as a surveillance station.
SOVAL: We were observing a dangerous and aggressive neighbour. The
Andorians wouldn't have found the station if your people hadn't
interfered. They've been in space for six months and they've already
destabilised an entire sector.
FORREST: I'm afraid I can't agree with that, Ambassador. This was a
volatile situation long before Starfleet got involved. Perhaps if you'd
been a little more open with us, this tragedy might have been avoided.
SOVAL: We warned you something like this would happen. He's too
impulsive. Captain Gardner would have made a far more suitable
commanding officer.
FORREST: The Vulcan Consulate doesn't make command assignments here.
SOVAL: There was a time when your people sought our guidance. I regret
that time has passed. I've been recalled to Vulcan for consultation. In
the meantime, our joint fleet operations have been suspended.
AIDE [OC]: Yes, Admiral?
FORREST: Get me Captain Archer.
AIDE [OC]: Aye sir.
 [Captain's mess]
 TUCKER: I noticed we changed course overnight.
ARCHER: I found a new system in the Vulcan database. Coridan. They're
only a few light years away so I thought we'd take a look.
TUCKER: Inhabited?
ARCHER: Just over three billion humanoids. Apparently, the Vulcans have
a mining agreement with them. I had Hoshi send a message to their
Chancellor and she invited us to visit their capital city.
TUCKER: Then I'll start shining my boots.
ARCHER: I think I'll just take Hoshi, this time. The Chancellor asked
me to limit the number of people I bring down until they get to know us
better.
TUCKER: Oh.
ARCHER: It's really too bad. According to the database, they've got the
largest starship construction yards in the sector. They're supposed to
have ships that can run circles around the Vulcans.
TUCKER: Better than six five?
ARCHER: They say some Coridan ships have reached warp seven, but that's
just a rumour.
TUCKER: Warp seven?
ARCHER: You should lend Hoshi your camera. I'll be sure she takes lots
of pictures.
(Archer finally cracks and grins.)
TUCKER: You had me going there for a minute.
ARCHER: You're just too easy a target.
TUCKER: So you're taking me, right?
HOSHI [OC]: Bridge to Captain Archer.
ARCHER: Go ahead.
HOSHI [OC]: I'm receiving a transmission from Starfleet Command. It's
Admiral Forrest, sir.
 [Ready room]
 ARCHER: Was anyone killed?
FORREST [on monitor]: The Andorians gave the monks three hours before
they started their bombardment. Fortunately, they all got out in time.
ARCHER: How are the Vulcans taking this?
FORREST [on monitor]: Not well.
ARCHER: I can't really blame the Andorians for reacting this way.
FORREST [on monitor]: Jon.
ARCHER: If the roles were reversed the Vulcans might have done the same
thing.
FORREST [on monitor]: The Vulcans may have good reason for keeping an
eye on them. I've seen the reports. These Andorian commandos are a
dangerous group.
ARCHER: That's the same crap the Vulcans used to say about us.
FORREST [on monitor]: Jon, you're doing a lot of good work, but you've
got to be more careful. Earth can't be getting involved in
inter-species conflicts.
ARCHER: I understand.
FORREST [on monitor]: I'm afraid I've got some more bad news.
(Later, Archer is staring out of the window when the door bell sounds.)
ARCHER: Come in. Have a seat.
(T'Pol sits.)
ARCHER: I just spoke with Admiral
Forrest. There's no easy way to say this. The Andorians destroyed the
sanctuary at P'Jem.
T'POL: Were there any survivors?
ARCHER: Fortunately, the monks and the intelligence operatives were
given advance warning. They're fine.
T'POL: Was there time to remove any of the relics?
ARCHER: I don't know. The High Command believes we're to blame for
this. They're sending a ship to take you back to Vulcan. It'll be here
in two days.
T'POL: I won't have time to complete my scans of this sector. I'll ask
Ensign Mayweather to finish them.
ARCHER: Maybe I wasn't clear. This isn't a temporary transfer. They're
reassigning you.
T'POL: I understand the situation, Captain. I'm certain the High
Command will find you a suitable replacement.
ARCHER: Am I the only one who has a problem with this? Because you seem
perfectly fine.
T'POL: My assignment to the Enterprise was only supposed to last eight
days. It was unrealistic to expect it to continue indefinitely.
ARCHER: The High Command is looking for a scapegoat, someone to blame.
They can't punish me so they're taking it out on my science officer.
Sounds like an emotional reaction, if you ask me.
T'POL: I am largely responsible for what happened.
ARCHER: Don't give yourself too much credit. I was the one who found
P'Jem in the database, and I led the landing party. I want you to know
I'm filing a protest with the High Command.
T'POL: That won't make any difference.
ARCHER: You don't know that.
T'POL: Captain, I was assigned to Enterprise not simply as an observer,
but to represent the interests of the Vulcan people. It's clear in the
eyes of my superiors I haven't done that.
ARCHER: They have no right to do this to you. You're a part of my crew.
T'POL: For another forty eight hours. Was there anything else?
ARCHER: No.
 [Corridor]
 TUCKER: This is just another part of the joke,
right?
ARCHER: Sorry, Trip, but I've got to take T'Pol on this one. I need to
spend some time with her alone.
TUCKER:: Now I know you're pulling my leg.
ARCHER: T'Pol's being transferred. A Vulcan ship's on its way to take
her back.
TUCKER: What?
ARCHER: Meet me for lunch. I'll fill you in.
 [Mess hall]
 PHLOX: May I? I just heard about your transfer.
I'm sorry you'll be leaving us. I'm sure you'll excel at whatever new
assignment you're given.
T'POL: I haven't received another assignment.
PHLOX: I assumed you were being promoted.
T'POL: My superiors believe that I'm responsible for the destruction of
the P'Jem sanctuary.
PHLOX: Do you agree with their assessment?
T'POL: It's the logical conclusion.
PHLOX: I'm certain the High Command would reconsider your transfer if
they knew everything you've done for this crew. You realise you're not
the first Vulcan officer to be posted aboard a human starship. The High
Command has tried this before but none of the others lasted more than a
few weeks. They found their crewmates too chaotic and unpredictable.
But you've been here more than six months and you haven't merely
tolerated this crew, you've become part of it. Isn't it logical to take
pride in that accomplishment?
T'POL: Pride is a human indulgence.
PHLOX: I suppose it is. Oh, I have it on good authority that several
crewmembers are planning a gathering in your honour. I believe it's
called a going-away party. I'd keep on alert if I were you.
 [Shuttlepod]
 (En route to the Coridan capital city.)
ARCHER: So, what do you know about Coridan?
T'POL: There are three billion inhabitants, mostly concentrated in
several cities in the equatorial region.
ARCHER: I wasn't asking for the statistics. Your people have been
coming here for decades. You must know something about their culture,
the kinds of food they eat, what they do for fun.
T'POL: The Vulcan database doesn't contain that information.
ARCHER: Of course not.
T'POL: I am uncertain why I was chosen for this mission.
ARCHER: These people have never seen humans before. It makes sense for
someone with a familiar face to make the introductions.
T'POL: I have a lot of work to complete before the Vulcan ship arrives.
ARCHER: Don't worry, I'll get you back in plenty of time. I just
thought you might enjoy one final mission with your Captain. Or maybe I
should just take you back to Enterprise.
T'POL: We're only a few minutes from the capital. Returning to the ship
now would be a waste of fuel.
TUCKER [OC]: Enterprise to Captain Archer.
ARCHER: Go ahead, Trip.
TUCKER [OC]: We're reading a ship closing on you, fast.
ARCHER: I got it.
T'POL: Some kind of fixed wing aircraft.
ARCHER: Did the Chancellor say anything about sending an escort? (hit
by weapons fire)
T'POL: I don't think they're an escort.
ALIEN [OC]: Alien vessel. Reduce to one quarter power and adjust
heading to three one seven mark five.
ARCHER: I'm taking evasive action. Bring the plasma weapons online.
T'POL: Ready.
ARCHER: Fire.
(They miss.)
 [Room]
 (Water pours through gaps in the roof, light
shines through holes in the corrugated walls.)
ARCHER: Houdini could get out of this.
(The pair are thoroughly trussed
up back to back, with bags over their heads.)
T'POL: Perhaps you should invite him on your next mission.
ARCHER: Harry Houdini was a magician, an escape artist. He was famous
for being able to free himself from any kind of restraint. Rope,
chains, anything.
T'POL: (struggling) That seems unlikely.
ARCHER: That's why he was called a magician. Some people say he was
double-jointed. I don't suppose Vulcans are double-jointed.
T'POL: Unfortunately not.
(A light comes on and the door is unlocked. The bags are removed from
their heads. Three people are there, male humanoids, bumpy foreheads,
slit down the nose, no upper lip.)
TRAEG: A Vulcan. What brings you to Coridan?
ARCHER: If you want answers, talk to me.
TRAEG: You're her superior?
ARCHER: That's right.
TRAEG: I don't recognize your species.
ARCHER: I'm human, from the planet Earth.
TRAEG: Never heard of Vulcans taking orders from anyone.
ARCHER: There's been a misunderstanding. We're here at the invitation
of your Chancellor.
TRAEG: She's not my Chancellor. That government is kept in power by the
Vulcans. If you're with them, you're on the wrong side.
(Traeg pulls a phase
pistol from his pocket.)
TRAEG: What kind of weapon is this? If you won't tell me
(He aims it at T'Pol.)
ARCHER: It's a phase pistol.
TRAEG: We'll put these to good use. I'm curious about your starship.
What can you tell me about it?
ARCHER: Our protein resequencer can make chicken sandwiches.
(He gets hit
for his cheek.)
T'POL: Stop! He's not a tactical officer. He's the ship's steward.
We're here to prepare a banquet for your Chancellor.
TRAEG: Your people have a reputation for truthfulness. You wouldn't be
lying to me, would you, Vulcan? Now I understand. You're the Captain,
aren't you?
T'POL: Perhaps.
TRAEG: Whoever you are, you picked the wrong time for a visit.
(The
group leaves, turning off the light.)
ARCHER: A steward?
 [Situation room]
 CHANCELLOR [on monitor]: We believe your shuttle
was forced down by members of a radical faction, but since the attack
took place outside our sensor grid, your officers won't be easy to
find.
TUCKER: You didn't tell us about any factions.
CHANCELLOR [on monitor]: They're a small group. We had no idea they
were capable of an attack like this. But be assured, Commander, your
people are almost certainly still alive.
REED: Almost certainly?
CHANCELLOR [on monitor]: The radicals will want something in exchange
for the hostages. They always do. Side arms, dicobalt explosives. It's
important that you don't give them anything.
REED: Is this how you protect your visitors?
TUCKER: You might have told us about your little war before you invited
us down.
CHANCELLOR [on monitor]: We're not at war, Commander. This is an
isolated incident.
TUCKER: I don't care what you call it. We just want to know where are
people are.
CHANCELLOR [on monitor]: We are doing everything in our power to find
them. (ends transmission)
TUCKER: We're not going to sit on our hands and wait for a ransom note.
Start scanning for human and Vulcan biosigns. (all walk forward to
their bridge stations)
HOSHI: There are billions of people down there. It could take days.
TRAVIS: It might be easier to locate the shuttlepod.
HOSHI: I'll try, but if the pod's been powered down it's almost
impossible to pick up its signature.
TUCKER: We've got to start somewhere.
 [Room]
 ARCHER: Ready?
T'POL: Yes.
ARCHER: Go.
(They try to stand by pushing against each other.)
ARCHER: Easy.
(With their feet tied together, it's difficult.)
ARCHER: Come on. Go.
(They try
again and fall on their sides.)
ARCHER: I think we got a little higher that
time.
T'POL: Only a few centimetres.
ARCHER: That's not frustration I hear in your voice.
T'POL: No.
ARCHER: Good. Let's try it again. One, two, three.
(They get back to a
sitting position.)
ARCHER: Ready?
T'POL: Yes.
ARCHER: Go.
(They succeed in standing.)
ARCHER:  I think these are starting to
come loose. How about yours?
T'POL: Slightly. If we can turn around, face each other.
ARCHER: We might be able to untie these knots. You'd think the Vulcan
database might have mentioned these people were fighting a civil war.
(T'Pol wriggles her way around his side within the ropes around their
waists.)
T'POL: The database is accurate. The Coridan government doesn't view
this as a civil war.
ARCHER: I imagine your people are going to want their database back,
too. Well, they can have it.
(They are finally face to face.)
ARCHER: Can you
reach the knot?
T'POL: I believe so. Without the database you wouldn't have found this
planet, or P'Jem.
ARCHER: You're not responsible for what happened. You didn't have any
idea that your people had installed a listening post, or that there
were Andorian commandos there.
T'POL: Enterprise had no good reason to visit a Vulcan sanctuary. I had
the opportunity to protest but I chose not to.
(Their wrists are now
untied.)
T'POL: It's clear that living among humans has caused my reasoning to
become compromised.
(They reach around each others waists to free
themselves.)
ARCHER: I think I understand. You're running away because you're afraid
to become one of us.
T'POL: I am not running away.
ARCHER: Then why aren't you fighting this transfer?
(Still reaching behind
each other,)
ARCHER: Your people took something away from my father that meant a
lot to him. They're not going to do the same thing to me.
(They
overbalance, and she lands on top on him. Finally they get free of each
other and start to release their own legs, but the door opens and a
guard comes in. Archer tackles him and takes him down.)
ARCHER: Go get his
weapon.
TRAEG: Stop!
 [Bridge]
 REED: It's definitely a ditanium signature about
four kilometres outside the capital.
TUCKER: It's practically under their noses.
REED: From what we can tell, the entire capital is surrounded by a
shanty town. There are almost as many biosigns on the outskirts as
there are inside the city.
TUCKER: Looks like these people have a lot to learn about building a
free society. Have you found human or Vulcan biosigns?
REED: Not yet.
TUCKER: What about the pod's transponder?
REED: They must have switched it off. Sir, I've got a rescue team
standing by in the launch bay.
TUCKER: Hold on, Malcolm. We don't even know if this is our pod. I
don't want to go down and find it's some alien tractor.
REED: It's our shuttlepod. I'm certain of it. All I'm suggesting is we
go down and have a look around.
HOSHI: Sir, we're being hailed. Audio only.
TUCKER: Who is it?
HOSHI: I can't tell.
TUCKER: Put them through.
TRAEG [OC]: Is this Enterprise?
TUCKER: Yes. And you are?
TRAEG [OC]: We're holding your Captain and your steward. In exchange
for their safe return we want forty of your phase weapons, the same
type we found aboard your shuttle. You'll be hailed at this time
tomorrow.
TUCKER: Wait, let me talk to the Captain.
TRAEG [OC]: I'm sure you wouldn't want any harm to come to her. We'll
rely on your full compliance.
TUCKER: Hello?
HOSHI: They've cut transmission.
TUCKER: Were you able to trace it?
HOSHI: They were using a triaxilating signal.
REED: They called the Captain 'her'. Are we sure they've got the right
hostages?
TRAVIS: At least it sounds like they're still alive.
REED: For how long? We don't have forty phase pistols, we've got
fifteen, and even if we give them to these people there's no guarantee
they'll keep their word. We know where the shuttle is. We have to send
a team down now while we still have the element of surprise.
HOSHI: We're getting another transmission.
TUCKER: Probably thought of something else they want.
HOSHI: It's not from the planet. It's coming from a Vulcan ship, the
Ni'Var.
TUCKER: Put it up.
SOPEK [on viewscreen]: Where's Captain Archer?
TUCKER: He's not here right now. Can I help you?
SOPEK [on viewscreen]: Inform him that we'll be arriving within the
hour.
TUCKER: You guys made great time. We weren't expecting you until
tomorrow.
SOPEK [on viewscreen]: You obviously made an error in your
calculations. Please have Sub-commander T'Pol ready to depart when we
arrive.
TUCKER: We've got a bit of a problem. She's not here either. She and
the Captain were on their way to the capital city when they were
kidnapped.
SOPEK [on viewscreen]: How convenient.
TUCKER: I'm telling you, they were kidnapped.
SOPEK [on viewscreen]: How do you know this?
TUCKER: Maybe the ransom demand we just received gave us a clue. They
threatened to kill them both if we didn't give them what they want.
SOPEK [on viewscreen]: It would be irrational to kill the hostages.
They would lose their negotiating position.
TUCKER: Maybe we're not dealing with the most rational people down
there, did you consider that?
SOPEK [on viewscreen]: Since the situation involves a Vulcan officer,
we will take over the investigation. It would be best if you refrained
from any foolish endeavours.
TUCKER: What the hell's that supposed
(Transmission ends.)
TUCKER: I'm getting
real sick of being cut off.
 [Situation room]
 SOPEK: Your vessel is ill-equipped to mount a
rescue mission. You would most likely become captives yourselves. My
team will penetrate their base of operations.
TUCKER: What does that mean?
REED: Sounds to me like you're planning an assault.
TUCKER: Did it ever occur to you that that could get the Captain and
T'Pol killed?
SOPEK: We've dealt with this sort of threat in the past. Swift,
decisive action is the logical response.
TUCKER: You're awfully trigger-happy for someone who's repressed his
emotions.
SOPEK: They've threatened the life of a Vulcan officer. We must
discourage any such incidents in the future.
REED: This isn't your planet. Maybe the Coridan government has
something to say about this.
SOPEK: I've already been in contact with the Chancellor. She's given me
full authority to implement this action.
TUCKER: You don't really care what happens to them, do you? You
probably wouldn't mind if they got caught in the crossfire. You'd
consider it payback for what happened at P'Jem.
SOPEK: It is not Vulcan policy to negotiate with terrorists.
(Sopek turns to
leave.)
TUCKER: Not even if it saves lives?
SOPEK: Any data you may have on the location of your Captain and the
Sub-Commander would be useful.
TUCKER: Sorry, we don't have anything.
(The Vulcans leave.)
TUCKER: Warm up the
shuttlepod.
 [Room]
 (The pair are even more thoroughly tied, with
ropes connecting ankles to knees and wrists and then to necks. A guard
brings them a plate of food each and places it at their feet.)
ARCHER: We can't eat like this.
(The guard leaves.)
ARCHER: Friendly.
(He has to lie
down on the floor to get a finger to the bowl.)
ARCHER: Can you pick up yours?
T'POL: No.
(Archer takes a lick of the stuff on the plate.)
ARCHER: Dig in,
Sub-commander. I don't think you'll be able to send this back for some
plomeek broth.
T'POL: I'm not hungry.
ARCHER: I didn't ask if you were hungry. You need to keep up your
strength, so eat. That's an order.
(She lies down and dips a finger in
the stuff. Archer discovers a red flashing light in his bowl.)
ARCHER: Look at
this.
 [Bridge]
 HOSHI: We're being hailed. It's the Vulcans.
TRAVIS: Here we go.
SOPEK [on viewscreen]: This is Sopek. Where's Commander Tucker?
HOSHI: He's unavailable at the moment. Can I take a message?
SOPEK [on viewscreen]: I want to know where that shuttlepod was going.
HOSHI: What shuttlepod is that?
SOPEK [on viewscreen]: The one that left your launch bay nine minutes
ago.
HOSHI: I really wouldn't know, sir. We get shuttlepods coming and going
all the time. It's a little like Union Station around here.
(She starts
messing with the transmission frequency on her board.)
SOPEK [on viewscreen]: I want to know where Commander Tucker is.
HOSHI: I'm sorry, your transmission's breaking up.
 [Shanty town]
 TUCKER: I guess not everyone gets to live in
Emerald City.
REED: Yeah.
(They get jumped and dragged off with bags over their heads.)
 [Another room]
 (The bags are removed.)
SHRAN: You should have listened to the Vulcan. He warned you against
doing anything foolish.
TUCKER: What the hell are you doing here?
SHRAN: Looking out for you pink skins. If you had gone anywhere near
that shuttlepod, you'd have been killed.
THOLOS: They left it in the open for you to find.
TUCKER: How do you know what Sopek told me? That was a secure
transmission.
SHRAN: Sopek is the senior Vulcan officer in the sector. Naturally, we
keep him under close surveillance. We've been monitoring all Vulcan
transmissions and ship deployments since the incident at P'Jem. We know
they're preparing for a war against us.
TUCKER: I'm no fan of the Vulcans, but they're not warmongers.
SHRAN: There's already a war going on, and the Vulcans are in the
middle of it. Several rebel factions here are working to overthrow
their government, a corrupt government that has very close ties to your
peace loving, logical friends.
REED: So, you and the rebels figure you both have a common enemy.
SHRAN: The hostage-takers have no plans to return your Captain or the
female. Once you deliver the weapons, they'll be killed. Fortunately
for you, we have a relationship with the down-trodden here.
TUCKER: You tried to kill us last time we met. Why are you trying to
help us now?
SHRAN: I haven't slept well since our encounter at the Vulcan
sanctuary. I don't like being indebted to anyone, least of all your
Captain.
(Tholos unties the pair.)
TUCKER: You're right. You never would have found that spy station
without his help.
SHRAN: Once he's free, my debt will be repaid in full. Show them.
(Tholos brings up images on a monitor.)
SHRAN: Your people are being held here.
These are barracks for the guards.
REED: How many?
THOLOS: At least four inside the compound, two more up on the wall
here, and two guards outside the gate. All armed with particle weapons.
TUCKER: How'd you get this level of detail?
SHRAN: We have an operative inside the compound.
REED: Unless he's going to take out these guards, you're not going to
have an easy time getting all the way to the hostages.
(Shran gets weapons from a box.)
SHRAN: It's not your concern.
TUCKER: It is if you get the Captain killed. You're outnumbered four to
one. Wouldn't you like to improve those odds?
THOLOS: They could be useful.
SHRAN: Give them their weapons.
 [Room]
 TUCKER [OC]: Captain, can you hear me?
ARCHER: Trip?
TUCKER [OC]: It's me and Malcolm, sir. We're about half a kilometre
away.
ARCHER: Just the two of you?
TUCKER [OC]: Not exactly. We met up with some old friends down here.
Andorians. Apparently, one of them thinks he owes you a favour.
ARCHER: He couldn't have picked a better time.
TUCKER [OC]: One of the people guarding you is working with them. When
he unties you, head for the gate. It's about twenty metres from the
building you're in. Until he shows up, just sit tight.
ARCHER: That won't be a problem.
 [Compound gate]
 TUCKER: Cold, isn't it? Andorian ale?
(Tucker offers a
bottle to two sentry guards.)
TUCKER: It'll warm you up.
(One takes a swig while
the inside man sneaks past and peels back some corrugated sheeting to
let Shran and Tholos in. Putting the metal back makes a noise.)
GUARD: Who's that?
TUCKER: Oh, it's just my friend. Nothing to
(One guard goes to
investigate, the other slams Tucker against the wall, interrupting his dialogue.)
TUCKER: Get off me. Hey,
let me go.
(More guards are attracted to the disturbance, and Tucker knocks out
his assailant with the bottle while the Andorians take out two more.
Reed joins Trip at the gate and Shran lets them in. They head in but
there is an explosion at the gate.)
TUCKER: What the hell is going on?
(Vulcans come through the hole they've created and start a gun fight
with the remaining guards.)
 [Room]
 (Shran's agent comes to free Archer and T'Pol but
gets shot in the back.)
ARCHER: Get down.
(They lie on the floor.)
 [Compound]
 SHRAN: Vulcans! Did you know they were planning to
do this?
TUCKER: You're the ones who have their comm. system bugged.
REED: Our escape plan's shot to hell.
TUCKER: We've got to get them out of there.
(Shran and Trip run for the room Archer and T'Pol are in while Reed
gives covering fire against the Coridans)
 [Room]
 TUCKER: Good to see you, Captain.
ARCHER: What's going on?
Tucker unties Archer while Shran frees T'Pol.)
TUCKER: Vulcans crashed our
rescue party.
ARCHER: (getting a hand up from Shran) Thanks.
SHRAN: I believe this is yours. It's the scanner she gave me from the
Vulcan listening post.
ARCHER: Seems you went to a lot of trouble to return it.
SHRAN: I'm here for only one reason. I need a good night's sleep. My
debt is repaid.
(The Vulcans bring in a howitzer and the fight is over.)
 [Compound]
 SOPEK: Your presence here is a violation of the
Tau Ceti Accords.
SHRAN: You lecture us about treaty violations?
SOPEK: Put down your weapons!
SHRAN: I know better than to lower my guard around Vulcans.
ARCHER: Look, we're all on the same side here.
(T'Pol sees Traeg aim a weapon at Sopek, so she moves to push him aside
and gets shot in the back herself. Shran and Tholos shoot the would-be
assassin.)
ARCHER: Let's get her to the ship.
SOPEK: She's no longer your responsibility. We'll treat her on the
Ni'Var.
(Archer picks T'Pol up.)
ARCHER:
She's still my Science Officer. Is the pod
close?
REED: Yes, sir.
ARCHER: Let's go.
(They head out.)
SHRAN: (to Sopek) You should be the one dying, not her.
 [Sickbay]
 SOPEK: How is she?
PHLOX: Her injuries were quite extensive.
SOPEK: Will she live?
PHLOX: I wish I could say.
ARCHER: I know how you must feel. She saved my life once too. She can
be a real pain in the ass. Stubborn, arrogant. Sometimes she makes me
angry enough, I want to shove her out an airlock. I can understand why
the High Command's upset, but it took a lot of courage to step in front
of that plasma bullet. Do you really want to take her back home in
disgrace?
SOPEK: Nothing can excuse what she did at the sanctuary.
ARCHER: I'm not asking anyone to pin a medal on her. All I'm asking is
that she be given a second chance. If a respected Vulcan captain went
before the High Command and made a plea on T'Pol's behalf, told them
how she saved the life of a superior officer, wouldn't they think twice
about this transfer?
SOPEK: I can't return without her.
PHLOX: She's suffered extreme trauma. I wouldn't advise moving her for
quite some time.
SOPEK: I'm meeting with the High Command in three days. Perhaps, if
there's time, I'll discuss this matter with them.
ARCHER: Thank you.
(Sopek and his aide leave. T'Pol has been
revived by a hypospray and is trying to sit up.)
T'POL: What happened?
ARCHER: Whoa, whoa, whoa. You were shot. Don't you remember?
T'POL: Captain Sopek?
ARCHER: He's all right, thanks to you.
T'POL: I'd like to return to my quarters.
PHLOX: I'm afraid you're going to have to stay here at least another
twenty four hours.
(Phlox leaves them.)
ARCHER: You made quite an impression on Sopek. I've got a feeling he's
going to talk to the High Command about that transfer order. I'd say
the odds are pretty good you're going to be with us for a while longer.
T'POL: You should have consulted me first.
ARCHER: It's probably not too late if you want to catch up to him.
T'POL: That won't be possible. Leaving Sickbay would violate my
doctor's orders.
