The Enterprise Transcripts - Doctor's Orders
Doctor's
Orders
 Original Airdate: 18 Feb, 2004

(Enterprise is travelling slowly through one of the special effects
department's ubiquitous purple hazes, and the ship appears deserted -
except for one canine running away from ...)
 [Corridor]
 PHLOX: Porthos, come back here. Porthos, stop.
Return. Heel, that's it. Heel. Porthos.
(Outside Archer's quarters, the faithful companion scratches at the
door and yips.)
PHLOX: All right, but just for a moment.
 [Archer's quarters]
 (Porthos jumps onto the still figure on the bed
and licks his face.)
PHLOX: That's enough. You can come and see him again tomorrow.
(Phlox picks Porthos up and leaves. Archer never even twitched.)
 [Phlox's quarters]
 PHLOX: (reading) It says here that canines can be
quite territorial. Is that why you keep returning to the Captain's
quarters? On Earth, a dog called Scruffers travelled three thousand
kilometres attempting to reunite with it's human keeper. I heard of a
Pycan space moth that drifted half a light year trying to return to
it's home world, but I don't believe it had a name. I could use a walk.
How about you?
 [Corridor]
 PHLOX: (dictating) Dear Doctor Lucas. I apologise
in responding to your last letter. As you can imagine, the crew and I
have been quite busy.
 [Galley]
 PHLOX: In we go. I
was deeply saddened to hear about your colleagues lost in the Xindi
attack. You have my condolences. It's unfortunate you were forced to
cut your time on Denobula short, but obviously you're needed on Earth.
Perhaps when our mission is successfully completed I'll see you back in
San Francisco. The Expanse. An extremely curious place. (He takes
something from a jar labeled Dr Phlox - do not eat.) PHLOX: For example, we've
recently encountered a phenomenon that, er. (to Porthos) Do you want
one of these? I doubt you'd like it. It's a leech, you know. It will
clean out your intestinal tract. Don't tell the Captain. (Porthos
catches the morsel.) PHLOX: I apparently find myself in somewhat unsettling
circumstances, Doctor Lucas. Although they have allowed me the luxury
of catching up on my correspondence.
(Phlox eats a leech himself.)
 [Situation room]
 PHLOX [OC]: We first encountered the phenomenon
responsible for this situation two days ago.
T'POL: It's directly on our route to Azati Prime.
ARCHER: Why didn't sensors pick it up before now?
T'POL: Because it wasn't there before now. It's similar to the
phenomenon we encountered several weeks ago.
ARCHER: A trans-dimensional disturbance.
T'POL: This region is being rapidly reconfigured as we speak.
ARCHER: How long would it take to go around it?
T'POL: Two weeks.
REED: Another detour.
T'POL: Perhaps not. Since this region was formed only recently, it
hasn't been completely reconfigured. We should still be able to cross
it safely.
TUCKER: You said nothing from our universe could survive inside these
things.
T'POL: Doctor.
PHLOX: That's true, unless we take the appropriate precautions. The
reconfigured space disrupts the human neocortex, but I can counteract
the effects by dampening the crew's neurological activity. It would be
like, oh, shutting down the main computer to protect it from an ion
storm.
TUCKER: How do you plan to shut down our neocortexes?
PHLOX: Quite simply, I can place each of you in a comatose state until
we've passed through the affected region.
ARCHER: How quickly can we get across it?
T'POL: Less than an hour at warp four.
TUCKER: I don't want to risk going to warp in there. Who knows what
kind of effect this disturbance will have on our warp field. We'll be
safer sticking to impulse. You'll have to keep us in comas for at least
four days.
REED: That's still less time than it would take to go around it.
ARCHER: Can you keep us under that long?
PHLOX: Shouldn't cause any problems.
 [Travis's quarters]
 PHLOX: Commander Tucker was none too keen on my
plan. However, I was able to convince Captain Archer. Since my
Denobulan physiology is immune to the effects of the disturbance, I
volunteered to watch over the crew. So far, they've been no trouble at
all.
 [Bridge - memory]
 (Phlox is getting a practical driving lesson.)
PHLOX [OC]: While the computer's controlling most of the ship's
systems, I was given a quick tutorial, just in case. Despite the dire
circumstances I must say I relished the challenge and soon developed a
new-found respect for Ensign Mayweather.
 [Engineering - memory]
 TUCKER: You need to check this every two hours,
minimum.
PHLOX: Every two hours.
TUCKER: If the impulse manifolds get clogged, the engines'll overload.
That would be very bad.
PHLOX: I imagine it would.
TUCKER: No offence, Doc, but under normal circumstances I wouldn't even
let you in here without four years of Starfleet training under your
belt.
PHLOX: These are hardly normal circumstances.
TUCKER: Listen. If something happens, something you can't handle, I
want you to wake me up.
PHLOX: I can't do that. Even a few minutes of exposure would cause
permanent damage.
TUCKER: If it comes down to saving the ship? Look, I'm making it easy
for you. Okay?
 [Archer's quarters]
 ARCHER: How's the rest of the crew doing?
PHLOX: Sleeping peacefully, except for you. Now, lie back.
ARCHER: Doctor.
PHLOX: Please, Captain, I've told you the procedure's completely safe.
ARCHER: I'm sure it is, but I
PHLOX: Captain, I have already had this discussion with Commander
Tucker, Lieutenant Reed and virtually every other officer on the ship.
I'm not comfortable being incapacitated, I really should be at my post,
I'm willing to risk staying awake. Well you can't, nor do you need to.
I assure you I have everything well in hand.
ARCHER: I know, Doctor. As Captain of the ship I'm the one who's
responsible for everyone aboard. There aren't many people I'd willingly
turn that responsibility over to. You're one of them.
PHLOX: Well, thank you, Captain.
ARCHER: I just wanted to say that before you put me under.
(Archer lies down on his bed, and Phlox does the deed.)
PHLOX [OC]: I must say, Doctor Lucas, that I appreciated the Captain's
vote of confidence. I had in fact been feeling some trepidation over
the responsibility I'd been handed, but after two days at the helm the
ship is running perfectly.
 [Engineering]
 (He hears a door slamming somewhere.)
PHLOX: Hello? Hello? (finds no one) Nonetheless, I'm not ashamed to
admit I'll be relieved when I can wake up the crew in two days, sixteen
hours and forty three minutes.
 [Sickbay]
 (Phlox jogs down a corridor, singing something Denobulan,
with Porthos following him. In Sickbay, strategically placed items spare our blushes as a
naked Phlox comes in to feed his menagerie.)
PHLOX: I know, I know, I'm sorry I'm late.
 [Mess hall]
 (Movie night is The Court Jester starring Danny
Kaye.)
HAWKINS: I don't want the vessel with the pestle, I want the chalice
from the what?
JEAN: The chalice from the palace.
WITCH: It's a little crystal chalice with a figure of a palace.
HAWKINS: The chalice from the palace have the pellet with the poison?
WITCH: No, the pellet with the poison's in the vessel with a pestle.
HAWKINS: Oh, oh, the pestle with the vessel.
JEAN: The vessel with a pestle.
HAWKINS: What about the palace from the chalice?
WITCH: Not the palace from the chalice! The chalice from the palace!
HAWKINS: Where's the pellet with the poison?
WITCH: In the vessel with a pestle!
JEAN: Don't you see? The pellet with the poison's in the vessel with
the pestle.
WITCH: The chalice from the palace has the brew that is true!
JEAN: It's so easy, I can say it!
HAWKINS: Well then you fight him!
WITCH: Listen carefully. The pellet with the poison's in the vessel
with a pestle, the chalice from the palace has the brew that is true.
HAWKINS: Where the pellet with the poison's in the vessel with a
pestle, the chalice from the palace has the brew that is true.
JEAN: Good man!
PHLOX: (to Porthos, his faithful companion) Did you hear that?
WITCH: Just remember that.
MAN: Sir Giacomo, into your armour, and you to your place in the
pavilion.
HAWKINS: The pellet with the poison, the pellet with the poison.
PHLOX: Computer, mute sound. (I have no idea what he hears) That
doesn't sound normal, does it. I suppose we should investigate, hmm.
I'm not going alone. Come, Porthos, come. (picks him up) I'd be better
off talking to my Pyrithian bat.
 [Corridor]
 PHLOX: Perhaps we are letting our imaginations run
away with us. I should never have let Mister Tucker talk me into
watching The Exorcist last week. (Another strange clunk.)
 [Launch bay]
 PHLOX: Hello? It's Doctor Phlox. (Porthos barks)
Porthos! Porthos, come back here. Porthos.
(He sees a vent of steam rattling a chain handrail.)
PHLOX: Well, now don't you feel foolish.
(A door closes, and he turns to see - and clutches at his heart.)
PHLOX: I called out. Didn't you hear me?
T'POL: I was running a diagnostic. Do you require my assistance? What
are you doing here? I thought it was movie night.
PHLOX: You could hear that all the way from the mess hall.
T'POL: I'll make a note of it in the maintenance log.
PHLOX: Bangs, squeaks, rattling chains. (He turns off the venting steam.)
PHLOX: Is this a starship or a haunted house?
T'POL: Are you all right, Doctor? You seem somewhat agitated.
PHLOX: Considering you nearly sent me into cardiac shock.
T'POL: I apologise if I startled you. You're certain that's all?
PHLOX: I have had a slight headache since we entered this region.
Perhaps Vulcans and Earth canines are better able to adapt to it than
Denobulans. How are you? I've barely seen you the last two days.
T'POL: I've had my duties to attend to. The rest of the time I've spent
in my quarters, reading, meditating.
PHLOX: Then you're due for a night out. Why don't you join Porthos and
me?
T'POL: I'd like to complete the diagnostic.
PHLOX: The movie's quite amusing.
T'POL: No, thank you.
PHLOX: T'Pol, I, er, perhaps you'll share a meal with me later.
T'POL: If you like.
 [Engineering]
 (Another door sound.)
PHLOX: Hello? (and again) T'Pol? Is that you? (It seems like someone runs
along the upper walkway.) PHLOX: Stop! Phlox to T'Pol.
T'POL [OC]: Go ahead.
PHLOX: Would you mind not creeping around the ship like a Draxxan cloud
viper.
T'POL [OC]: Doctor?
PHLOX: Please. I wouldn't have imagined that Vulcans engaged in
childish games.
T'POL [OC]: I don't understand.
PHLOX: What were you doing in Engineering just now?
T'POL [OC]: Doctor, I'm on the Bridge.
 [Galley]
 PHLOX: I hope you don't mind eating here in the
galley. Mess hall seems a bit, er, oh, melancholy. All the empty
chairs.
T'POL: This is fine.
PHLOX: My fifth grandmother made this for each of my weddings (ladling
liquid). Chef's tried to prepare it, but he never gets it quite right.
T'POL: Yes, his plomeek broth leaves something to be desired as well.
PHLOX: I always thought so, but was afraid to mention it. T'Pol, you're
sure you weren't in Engineering today?
T'POL: Quite sure. What were you doing there? I'm responsible for
monitoring the engines.
PHLOX: We're supposed to be assisting each other. It's a large ship for
two people to maintain.
T'POL: Do you have anything to report? Doctor?
PHLOX: I could have sworn there was someone in that room with me.
T'POL: A member of the crew?
PHLOX: No, everyone except us is in deep neuro-sedation.
T'POL: Then obviously you were mistaken.
PHLOX: Obviously. You've never been to Denobula, have you.
T'POL: No.
PHLOX: The cities are quite crowded, by choice, not by necessity. The
atmosphere is vibrant, communal.
T'POL: It sounds fascinating.
PHLOX: What I'm saying is that we're a sociable people. Being alone on
Enterprise, just the two of us, has proven more stressful than I
imagined. Two people aren't even enough for a Denobulan marriage, a
proper one anyway.
T'POL: I'm sorry I haven't been better company.
PHLOX: That isn't what I meant.
T'POL: I know. It is ironic, however, that I should be your sole
companion. Unlike your people, most Vulcans will go to great lengths to
find solitude. At times it has been trying for me to co-exist with
eighty humans. Especially the more irrational ones.
PHLOX: Such as Commander Tucker.
T'POL: I've found the last two days to be a welcome respite.
PHLOX: I understand, but I for one will never complain again when I
can't get a good seat on movie night.
(T'Pol has not touched the food)
 [Sickbay]
 PHLOX: (dictating) Despite the tragic
circumstances surrounding your homecoming, Doctor Lucas, you must be
happy to return to Earth. As I've mentioned before, I've no regrets
about accepting my position on Enterprise. However, it has struck me
recently how much I miss the familiar pleasures of my home.
 [Corridor]
 PHLOX: You've experienced the nightclubs in our
Kaybin district, so you know the excitement of meeting a new companion
or two. The intimacy that can develop so quickly when all parties are
receptive. You humans are a truly remarkable species, Doctor Lucas, but
when Enterprise has accomplished its mission I look forward to being
among Denobulans again. The more of them, the better.
 [Archer's quarters]
 PHLOX: Good afternoon, Captain. How are we feeling
today? Neurochemistry looks excellent, theta waves are good, you should
wake up extremely well rested. (There's a creaking noise. He looks out
of the porthole and recoils as something comes at him.) PHLOX: Phlox to T'Pol.
 [Bridge]
 T'POL: Internal sensors don't show any additional
biosigns.
PHLOX: I told you, it was outside of the ship, on the hull.
T'POL: There are no lifeforms anywhere in this vicinity.
PHLOX: What about alien vessels?
T'POL: You can see for yourself there's nothing there.
PHLOX: You said this reconfigured space could be affecting our systems.
What if it's interfering with our sensors?
T'POL: That's possible, but we should consider another explanation. You
mentioned you were having difficulty adjusting to the solitude of the
past few days.
PHLOX: I didn't imagine it! I saw something.
T'POL: Outside the ship, crawling on the hull.
PHLOX: What about what I saw in Engineering?
T'POL: You ran the scans yourself. There is nothing unusual on board.
You said you haven't slept much since we entered this disturbance.
Perhaps you should return to your quarters, try to rest.
PHLOX: I need to finish my rounds.
 [Hoshi's quarters]
 (He sees an Insectoid standing over Hoshi.)
PHLOX: Get away from her!
(It comes after him, so he runs down a corridor, sees the shadow of
another and hides in an airlock.)
 [Corridor]
 PHLOX: Phlox to T'Pol.
T'POL [OC]: Go ahead, Doctor.
PHLOX: It's the Xindi. They're on board.
 [Armoury]
 PHLOX: We'll need to arm ourselves. I saw two.
There could be more of them.
T'POL: There's nothing on sensors.
PHLOX: Then the sensors must be wrong.
T'POL: Doctor. Phlox! I thought you were going to get some rest.
PHLOX: They were real. I saw them.
T'POL: If that's true, then how did they get on the ship? All external
hatches and docking ports are sealed.
PHLOX: They could have transporter technology.
T'POL: There were no transporter signatures.
PHLOX: What difference does it make how they got on board. If we wake
up Lieutenant Reed or the MACOs they will be incapacitated in minutes,
dead within hours. It is up to us to deal with this situation. I plan
to start on G deck and work my way up. (She doesn't take the weapon he
offers her.) PHLOX: I'm going to stop them whether you help me or not.
 [Corridor]
 T'POL: We've searched four decks.
PHLOX: That leaves three to go.
T'POL: If there are Xindi aboard, why are they concealing themselves?
PHLOX: They could be trying to destroy Enterprise. What better time
than while the crew is incapacitated. (his scanner beeps) A biosign.
T'POL: There are over eighty biosigns aboard, not counting your pets in
Sickbay.
PHLOX: This isn't human.
T'POL: Neither are your pets.
PHLOX: I can't lock onto it.
T'POL: There must be some interference, possibly from the reconfigured
space.
PHLOX: You said it wasn't affecting our sensors.
T'POL: I said it wasn't affecting main sensors. That hand scanner is
far less powerful, you know that.
PHLOX: I have it. (further on) It's just ahead. (something comes round
the corner, Phlox fires and thankfully misses Porthos)
T'POL: Doctor!
PHLOX: It's all right. Fortunately I'm not very proficient with hand
weapons.
T'POL: How did he get out?
PHLOX: I, er, I believe I. We went for a walk earlier. I might have
neglected to put him back in my quarters.
T'POL: And you simply forgot.
PHLOX: I've been distracted. I would have thought this could tell the
difference between a giant insect and a beagle.
T'POL: It can, if you use it properly.
PHLOX: You're the science officer, you might have offered some
assistance in that area.
T'POL: You feel I haven't been helpful? How would you characterise the
two hours I wasted searching for a figment of your imagination?
PHLOX: I'm not delusional.
T'POL: Are you certain? As I recall, you once told Ensign Sato that
it's considered healthy for Denobulans to hallucinate. It's how you
release stress. You've been under a lot of stress lately, haven't you,
Doctor.
PHLOX: It's not unheard of, but I
T'POL: You said you've been having headaches. Is there anything else
you care to tell me?
PHLOX: I'm fine.
T'POL: You nearly shot the Captain's dog!
PHLOX: I'm going to recalibrate this to exclude canine biosigns and
then I'm going to finish searching this ship. I'm not seeing things and
I intend to prove it. (stomps off)
HOSHI [OC]: Ensign Sato to the Doctor.
PHLOX: Hoshi? Hoshi?
 [Hoshi's quarters]
 (The shower is running, her bed is empty.)
PHLOX: Ensign? Hoshi? What are you doing? I have to put you back under
sedation immediately. You'll suffer permanent damage. (He sees a
disfigured woman.) PHLOX: Hoshi?
HOSHI: You did this.
PHLOX: What?
HOSHI: You said we'd be safe.
PHLOX: Let me get you to Sickbay.
HOSHI: You promised us!
(Phlox backs away, falls over, then sees Hoshi lying peacefully on her bed.)
PHLOX: T'Pol, please meet me in Sickbay immediately.
 [Corridor outside turbolift]
 ARCHER: Where've you been? I was calling you.
PHLOX: Captain. What are you doing up?
ARCHER: T'Pol woke me. She said something was wrong.
PHLOX: I don't know what's happening.
ARCHER: She said you've been seeing things. Something about Xindi on
board the ship.
PHLOX: You're not concerned about that? (He starts backing away down the
corridor.)
ARCHER: I'm more concerned about you. I obviously expected too much
from you.
PHLOX: You're not real.
ARCHER: Why don't you go to your quarters. Lie down. I'll take over.
You did the best you could.
PHLOX: You are not real!
T'POL: Doctor.
(Phlox turns to look at her, and when he looks back, Archer has gone.)
 [Sickbay]
 PHLOX: I was so busy monitoring the crew I never
thought to run another neural scan on myself. The effects are subtle
and difficult to detect, but there are disruptions deep within my
neocortex. You were right. I was hallucinating.
T'POL: Are you in danger?
PHLOX: I don't believe there'll be any permanent damage. However, it's
obviously affecting my judgment. I have no choice but to put myself
under neuro-sedation and ask you to look after the crew.
T'POL: I don't have the medical expertise.
PHLOX: With your scientific background, you should have no problems.
T'POL: I have my own duties. I can't possibly monitor the entire crew.
PHLOX: It won't be for long. We'll be coming out of the disturbance in
less than six hours. T'Pol, I'm asking for your help.
T'POL: I can't.
PHLOX: Why not?
T'POL: When we were searching the ship, I became irritated with you.
PHLOX: Apparently, I deserved it.
T'POL: You don't understand. I was on the verge of losing control of my
emotions. This reconfigured space is effecting me as well.
PHLOX: Why didn't you tell me?
T'POL: I'd hoped to control it, but it's proven more difficult than I
thought. The crew is better off in your hands.
PHLOX: I doubt that. I nearly killed Porthos, remember. What if one of
these delusions causes me to open an airlock or shut down life support?
T'POL: You won't do that.
PHLOX: How do you know?
T'POL: Because your duty is to look out for the welfare of this crew.
Why do you think the Captain allowed you to sedate him over Commander
Tucker's objections? Because he trusts you, as do I.
PHLOX: I'm not sure I trust myself.
T'POL: Just a few more hours, Doctor.
 [Bridge]
 PHLOX [OC]: So, Doctor Lucas, while the past few
days have proven challenging, both T'Pol and I are relieved that our
adventure is nearly over.
PHLOX: (taking the helm) Once we've confirmed we're out of the
disturbance I can begin waking the senior officers. My medical staff
should be next. They can assist me with the rest of the(He gazes in
disbelief at a purple viewscreen.) PHLOX: We should have been out of the
disturbance half an hour ago.
T'POL: There could have been some slight navigational discrepancies.
PHLOX: I thought space travel was supposed to be precise.
T'POL: Not always. Check long range sensors. (Phlox dashes to the back of the Situation room.) PHLOX: What do you think
I'm doing. There's more than a slight discrepancy.
T'POL: This can't be correct. We're nearly a quarter of a light year
from the far edge.
PHLOX: At our current rate of speed we won't be out of this for another
ten weeks! Autonavigation is still engaged, engines are online, why
aren't we through?
T'POL: The reconfigured space has expanded.
PHLOX: But we knew it would. Travis said our course and speed would
compensate. T'Pol?
T'POL: Obviously the rate of acceleration has accelerated. We need to
increase speed.
PHLOX: We're already at full impulse.
T'POL: As you can see, that's insufficient. We need to go to warp.
PHLOX: Commander Tucker said it would be too dangerous. We don't know
what might happen.
T'POL: What do you propose? Keeping the crew comatose for the next ten
weeks?
 [Engineering]
 PHLOX: All right, what do we do first?
T'POL: I'm afraid I may not be of much assistance.
PHLOX: Do I need to keep reminding you, you are the Science Officer.
T'POL: I already told you, I'm finding it difficult to focus.
PHLOX: On your worst day you're more qualified to operate the warp
engines than I am.
T'POL: Unfortunately, this is by far one of my worst days.
PHLOX: I'm a physician, not an engineer.
T'POL: You hold a dozen scientific degrees.
PHLOX: None of them are in warp theory.
T'POL: The procedures for restarting the reactor are in the database.
PHLOX: You're suggesting I read the manual? (but he does, from a
screen) Output must be confined to within three hundred and three
hundred twelve millicochranes to prevent fusion of the dilithium
matrix.
T'POL: That seems simple enough.
PHLOX: Unless the spatial compression index is greater than five point
six two percent, or the ship is within two parsecs of a class C
gravimetric field distortion?
T'POL: I realise this is a complex procedure.
PHLOX: Complex? This is utterly baffling. It might as well be written
ancient Klingon for all the sense I can make of it. I'm sorry.
T'POL: I understand. I just wish I could be more helpful.
PHLOX: You're doing fine. We have to close the plasma relays before we
can begin the start-up sequence. Would you mind?
TUCKER: What the hell are you doing? I told you not to mess with the
warp engines.
PHLOX: I don't have time for this.
TUCKER: You'd better make time, Doc. I told you, you can't start the
warp reactor inside this disturbance.
PHLOX: Actually you told me it would be difficult, not impossible.
TUCKER: That machine was designed to manipulate space, to violate the
laws of motion. You make the tiniest mistake, you'll collapse the warp
field, you'll crush this ship.
PHLOX: Thank you for the warning.
TUCKER: You're going to screw this up, Phlox!
PHLOX: Go away.
TUCKER: You're going to kill everybody.
PHLOX: Can't you see I'm busy!
T'POL: Doctor, are you all right?
PHLOX: Fine.
T'POL: Doctor, I can't find the plasma relays.
PHLOX: I'll do it myself. (He goes to the main reactor controls.) PHLOX: Deuterium
pressure is nominal. Anti-matter constrictor coils are online. Warp two
should be sufficient.
T'POL: Shall we try?
(Bits of engine room start to light up.)
PHLOX: The intermix is stable. A warp field is forming.
(An alarm sounds.)
T'POL: What's wrong?
PHLOX: I don't know. (The ship shakes and the nacelles stutter.) PHLOX: I
followed the procedures exactly. What did I do wrong?
T'POL: You need to
PHLOX: What? What, T'Pol? Help me. Is it the particle confinement?
T'POL: Perhaps you should increase it.
PHLOX: How do I do that? (He dashes to his help screen.) PHLOX: Particle
confinement, particle confinement. (Things go bang.)
T'POL: Doctor, perhaps we should wake Commander
Tucker.
PHLOX: He'll die.
T'POL: If we destroy the ship, we'll all die.
PHLOX: I know.
T'POL: If we can't accomplish our mission, billions of people on Earth
could die. Isn't it logical to sacrifice one life to save so many?
PHLOX: I'm not willing to make that sacrifice yet. Particle
confinement. Increase power to the magnetic constriction coils. (She
can't touch the controls, and looks plaintively at him.) PHLOX: T'Pol! Here.
(He does it himself and the shaking stops.)
T'POL: The field is stabilising.
PHLOX: It's holding.
T'POL: Then I suggest we go to warp.
PHLOX: Engaging warp engines. Warp one point one, point two. (The
engine gets unhappy again.) PHLOX: Pressure on the hull's increasing.
T'POL: What are you doing?
PHLOX: Lieutenant Reed insisted on showing me how to transfer power to
the hull plating, just in case. It seems to be working. Warp one point
eight, one point nine, warp two!
 [Archer's quarters]
 (Safely back in normal space, Phlox removes the
neural inhibitor from Archer's forehead and gives him a hypo.)
ARCHER: Doctor.
PHLOX: Lie still. Your neocortex may need a few moments to warm up.
ARCHER: Are we through the disturbance?
PHLOX: Yes. I'll begin waking the rest of the crew shortly.
ARCHER: Any problems?
PHLOX: A few minor glitches. It will all be in my log. If you're
feeling up to it, you have a visitor.
ARCHER: Hey. (fondling Porthos) Thanks, Doctor.
 [Corridor]
 PHLOX: How are you feeling?
TUCKER: A little woozy.
PHLOX: I'm not surprised. You haven't eaten anything in four days. Get
to the Mess hall.
TUCKER: Aye, aye, Doc. (Tucker leaves.)
T'POL: I'll assist you in waking the others.
PHLOX: Oh, that won't be necessary. I appreciate the offer but you need
some rest. Let me walk you to your quarters.
T'POL: Doctor's orders?
 [T'Pol's quarters]
 T'POL: Thank you.
PHLOX: I'll stop by and check on you in a few hours. (He glances at the
bed and sees T'Pol lying there, comatose. The T'Pol he was talking to
has vanished.)
 [Mess hall]
 PHLOX [OC]: As you might guess, Doctor Lucas, I
had considered deleting this letter and starting over, since large
sections of it are now obviously fictitious. However, I decided that my
delusional account would probably prove entertaining. As always, you
have my best wishes. Your friend and colleague, Phlox.
PHLOX: May I join you?
T'POL: Of course. Commander Tucker was complaining that it will take
him days to realign the warp coils.
PHLOX: Yes, he gave me quite a talking to.
T'POL: He also said, and I quote, Phlox did one hell of a job. You must
have enjoyed having the ship to yourself.
PHLOX: It wasn't nearly as empty as I'd anticipated.

The Enterprise Transcripts - Hatchery
Hatchery
 Mission date: Jan 8, 2154
Original Airdate: 25 Feb, 2004
 
ARCHER: Previously on Enterprise
REED [Bridge]: The Insectoid ship's been damaged.
TUCKER: Target the second one.
HAYES [Cargo bay]: Is that what this is all about? You think that I want to replace
you?
REED: You just can't stand taking orders from me, can you.
HAYES: Tell me something.
REED: What.
HAYES: Why won't you let me do my job?
ARCHER [Brig]: I want to know where you're building the weapon.
DEGRA: I don't know what you're talking about.
ARCHER: The hell you don't.
HOSHI [Degra's ship]: There is a reference to a planet he visited recently. Azati
Prime.
T'POL [Command centre]: The coordinates match the location of one of the red giants.
ARCHER [Bridge]: Set a course to Azati Prime, maximum warp.
 [Bridge]
 (In orbit of a brown and white planet.)
ARCHER: Magnify. (There's a crashed ship on the surface.)
REED: It's definitely Xindi, sir. The hull composition matches the
other ships we've seen.
ARCHER: It doesn't look like a reptilian or a primate design. Biosigns?
T'POL: None that I can detect. There's no atmosphere aboard.
ARCHER: Anyone else in the system?
TRAVIS: No, sir.
ARCHER: Put a team together.
REED: Aye, sir.
 [Crashed ship]
 (The EV-suited team finds a couple of insectoid
bodies.)
ARCHER: We'll take them back to Enterprise. Tell Phlox I want a
complete autopsy. (to T'Pol) The Major and I will search the port side.
See if you can access their ship's database.
(Archer and Hayes find a closed door, and pries it up to reveal a huge
chamber. They investigate, while elsewhere -)
T'POL: It's a computer interface.
TUCKER: See what you can download.
REED: My father'd love to get a look at this place. He's fascinated by
insects, always filling the house up with bugs he's collected. Drives
my mother crazy.
TUCKER: Maybe we can bring home something new for his collection. (Tucker and Reed are at a bulkhead that Tucker's scanner has lead him to.)
REED: It's heavily
reinforced.
(They open the hexagonal hatch and step through.)
 [Hatchery airlock]
 (The hatch shuts automatically behind them.)
REED: It's pressurising. Oxygen nitrogen atmosphere.
TUCKER: After you. (Reed opens his helmet a little.)
REED: A little stale, but breathable.
Biosigns, very faint. Coming from in here. (Another hatch.)
 [Xindi shuttlebay]
 (investigating a craft inside the huge chamber)
HAYES: Some kind of shuttlecraft?
ARCHER: More like an assault vehicle. I'm reading a half dozen particle
cannons, torpedo launchers. Archer.
TUCKER [OC]: You'd better get over here, sir.
 [Hatchery]
 (Archer and Hayes enter the hatchery to find their
colleagues gazing in wonder at the things hanging from the ceiling, and
the fact that the power is on. They remove their helmets.)
T'POL: The DNA is identical to the bodies we found. They would appear
to be the crew's offspring.
ARCHER: A hatchery?
TUCKER: They built this place to take quite a beating. Reinforced
bulkheads, back-up power systems.
T'POL: Thirty one eggs are still viable.
TUCKER: They won't survive for long. The bio-support's losing power.
ARCHER: Do you think you can repair it?
TUCKER: I wouldn't even know where to start.
ARCHER: There's a shuttlecraft in their port bay. Get it back to the
ship. I want an analysis of their tactical systems as soon as possible.
REED: Aye sir. (He leaves with Tucker. Archer looks at a cluster of dangling eggs.)
ARCHER: Did you find their
Bridge?
T'POL: I'm not certain there is one. Their command functions appear to
be distributed through various (Archer gets splattered by a dangling
egg.) T'POL: Captain!
ARCHER: I'm all right.
T'POL: We should get you to Sickbay.
 [Sickbay]
 (Archer has a bright rash where the egg squirted
him.)
PHLOX: A mild neurotoxin. Likely part of an autonomic defence system.
The egg probably considered you a threat.
ARCHER: Humans seem to have that effect on the Xindi.
PHLOX: An analgesic should take care of the irritation.
ARCHER: Malcolm's bringing you two dead insectoids. I want you to learn
as much as you can about them.
PHLOX: Understood.
T'POL: We've located their Armoury. We found several particle weapons
and torpedo casings.
ARCHER: What about the data you recovered?
T'POL: Ensign Sato's translating it. We'll be ready to leave orbit as
soon as the Xindi shuttle's aboard.
 [Shuttlepod]
(Towing the Xindi shuttle, which is about the same
size.)
REED: We've cleared the thermosphere. (The pod shakes, and a corpse
falls over.) REED: You might want to do a better job securing our guests.
(Hayes kicks the bodybag.) REED: I think it's safe to assume it's dead.
HAYES: Just being cautious. (He puts it back on the bench and straps it
in.) HAYES: Certain insects on Earth are known to hibernate. (Hayes sits down and
draws his weapon.)
REED: Do you intent do shoot me, Major?
HAYES: It's not you I'm worried about. I've been going over the results
from the last training session. Your senior officers have shown a lot
of improvement, but I think they can do better. With your permission
I'd like to schedule some more target practice for Monday evening.
REED: That won't go over well with Commander Tucker. Monday night is
movie night.
HAYES: Maybe he can sacrifice some leisure time for the sake of this
mission.
REED: The senior officers do have other duties. We can't all spend our
time playing holographic games in the Armoury.
HAYES: I'm not sure that's how the Captain would see it.
HOSHI [OC]: Enterprise to Shuttlepod two. You're clear to approach.
REED: Acknowledged. Deploy the docking arm.
 [Ready room]
 ARCHER: Come in.
(T'Pol and Tucker enter.)
TUCKER: I think we figured out what happened to them. One of the
nacelles fractured when they were coming out of a subspace vortex. They
probably tried to make an emergency landing on this planet.
ARCHER: According to Phlox, the insectoids we found weren't killed in
the crash, they suffocated?
T'POL: Most of the crew appear to have died when they transferred their
life-support to the hatchery.
ARCHER: They sacrificed themselves to save their children. You said the
hatchery's losing biosupport. How long will it last?
TUCKER: Another day, at most.
ARCHER: I want you to assign a team to repair it.
TUCKER: Captain?
T'POL: What about Azati Prime?
ARCHER: It's not going anywhere. This is a sentient species. We can't
abandon them.
TUCKER: Captain, with all due respect, why the hell not? I've got half
a mind to take a plasma torch to that place.
ARCHER: What if we found a nursery filled with thirty one infant
primates. Would you want to torch them? The Xindi are trying to destroy
Earth because they heard that humans are ruthless. This is a chance to
prove them wrong.
T'POL: We can bring the eggs aboard, reconfigure one of the cargo bays.
ARCHER: I already talked to Phlox. He says they're integrated into the
hatchery walls. If we remove them, they'll die.
TUCKER: Sir, this is crazy. These people are trying to kill us.
ARCHER: This isn't open for discussion. I'll lead the engineering team.
I need you up here to help Travis figure out how to operate that Xindi
shuttle.
TUCKER: Captain.
ARCHER: I've made my decision. Get to work.
 Captain's Starlog, January 8th 2154. We've been in
orbit for more than a day. The crew is restless, eager to resume our
mission, but I'm certain my decision to stay was the right one.
 [Xindi shuttle]
 TUCKER: They may know how to make a weapon, but
these people could learn a thing or two about designing a comfortable
chair.
TRAVIS: For an Insectoid, maybe they are comfortable.
TUCKER: And the power grid doesn't make much sense. Almost half of it's
routed to structural integrity.
TRAVIS: You could probably fly this thing inside a gas giant.
TUCKER: Assuming you could figure out how to fly it.
TRAVIS: This icon looks like it might represent the impulse manifolds.
TUCKER: Give it a shot. (There's an Insectoid warning then the lights
go out.)
TRAVIS: I don't think this ship likes us very much.
 [Mess hall]
 REED: (using PADD) You're going to have to remove
the relays here and here. That should disable the security protocols.
TUCKER: We can't initialise the engines without them.
TRAVIS: What about the ship on the surface? We might be able to salvage
what we need.
TUCKER: Yeah.
REED: Any word on how much longer he's planning to stay in orbit?
TUCKER: The repairs are moving slow.
REED: I'd be the last to question the Captain's orders, but doesn't it
seem a little odd that we're staying here to save a nest of Xindi?
TUCKER: The Captain thinks it's the right thing to do. We may be at
war, but these creatures need our help.
REED: Meanwhile, their big brothers are trying to destroy Earth.
TRAVIS: Every day we stay here gives them more time to finish their
weapon.
TUCKER: Look, there's a chance we'll run into more insectoids when we
reach that red giant. Spending an extra day or two studying their
tactical systems might be useful.
 [Sickbay]
 (Phlox is in autopsy rubbers standing over an Insectoid with it's chest cavity open, when Archer comes in.)
PHLOX: Ah, Captain. I've learnt quite a bit about this fascinating
fellow. Perhaps fellow is the wrong word. Their species is genderless.
ARCHER: Then who made all those eggs?
PHLOX: They reproduce asexually. Each adult appears capable of
producing multiple egg sacs. I wouldn't be surprised if every insectoid
vessel had it's own hatchery. I'd estimate their lifespan is no more
than twelve Earth years. This individual may be one of the elder
members of the crew. It was nearly ten years old.
ARCHER: What about the hatchery? When will the eggs mature?
PHLOX: Without knowing more about their incubation cycle it's
impossible to say, but probably no more than a week at most. Captain,
if you don't mind my saying, you look as if you could use some rest.
ARCHER: We've got to get the repairs finished.
PHLOX: Surely a few hours sleep wouldn't
ARCHER: Contact me if you find anything else.
 [Hatchery airlock]
 (T'Pol has walked through the Xindi ship without
an EV suit.)
T'POL: Is there a problem, Corporal?
CHANG: No, ma'am.
T'POL: Why are you guarding this chamber?
CHANG: Captain's orders.
 [Hatchery]
 (Archer is working on the main life support
control unit in the middle of the chamber.)
T'POL: Lieutenant Reed's report.
ARCHER: What?
T'POL: You requested a tactical analysis of the Insectoid ship.
ARCHER: Later. Are we ready?
TUCKER: Just a few seconds, Captain.
T'POL: There are two MACOs posted outside.
ARCHER: I asked Major Hayes to assign them. These eggs are vulnerable.
There are breaches in the outer hull. There could be predators around.
T'POL: Aside from microbes, we found no evidence of life on this
planet.
ARCHER: Trip.
TUCKER: We're ready. Start at forty megajoules, but keep an eye on that
matrix converter. Take it up to fifty. (Systems start to light up, then
something goes bang.)
ARCHER: Trip. (An egg sac explodes and an engineer goes flying.) ARCHER: Shut it
down. What happened.
TUCKER: It must have been a surge in the power grid. I'll need a few
minutes, Captain.
(The burst sac contained two babies, one of which is moving slightly.)
ARCHER: Archer to Enterprise. Medical emergency.
 [Sickbay]
(Phlox holda the tiny stiff corpse in one hand.)
 PHLOX: There was nothing I could do. I'm sorry.
ARCHER: How's Hoshi coming with that translation.
T'POL: Their iconography is different from the other Xindi species.
It's taking some time.
ARCHER: When she's done, ask her to search their database. See if she
can locate anything about their burial rituals.
T'POL: Do you plan to hold a funeral?
TUCKER [OC]: Tucker to Captain Archer.
ARCHER: Go ahead.
TUCKER [OC]: I think I've figured out the problem. Their power grid
can't handle our converters.
 [Hatchery]
 TUCKER: It's going to take at least three days to
make them compatible.
 [Sickbay]
 ARCHER: What about the reactor? Any way to bring
it online?
TUCKER [OC]: It's possible
 [Hatchery]
 TUCKER: But they lost most of their antimatter in
the accident.
 [Sickbay]
 ARCHER: Stand by. Work with Trip. Help him get
their reactor up and running.
T'POL: Sir?
ARCHER: We're going to transfer our antimatter to their ship. Use as
much as you have to.
T'POL: Our reserves are at less than sixty percent.
ARCHER: I'm not going to let any more of them die.
 [Command centre]
 TUCKER: To get that reactor running again, we'll
have to use a third of our antimatter reserves.
REED: Why so much?
TUCKER: Every system on that ship is integrated. The only way to bring
biosupport back online is to power up the whole thing.
REED: That's not going to leave much antimatter for our torpedoes,
never mind our engines.
T'POL: Did you inform the Captain?
TUCKER: I wanted to run it by both of you first.
REED: I never imagined Captain Archer would put the welfare of a few
Xindi before his own people. Do you know, he spent nearly two days in
that hatchery. From what I'm told, he hasn't stopped working long
enough to even sleep!
T'POL: Delay the transfer for now.
TUCKER: The Captain gave us an order.
T'POL: I'll speak with him.
 [Hatchery]
 (Archer's still trying to repair a console, and
Hayes is standing guard)
ARCHER: Where's Trip? Did you bring the antimatter?
T'POL: No.
ARCHER: What's the problem?
T'POL: Initialising their reactor will deplete our reserves by over one
third.
ARCHER: We can spare it. We're only a few light years from the red
giant. We'll still have more than enough fuel get there.
T'POL: We don't know for certain if the weapon is in that system.
ARCHER: There are lives at risk here.
T'POL: Billions of lives are at risk on Earth if our mission fails.
ARCHER: I'm well aware of that. These Xindi are innocent. If we let
them die, we'll be proving to the others that they're right about us. I
don't know much about Vulcan ethics, but humans don't throw morality
out the window when things start getting a little rough.
T'POL: Commander Tucker and Lieutenant Reed also believe that this
would compromise our mission.
ARCHER: Your opinions have been noted. Now get back to Enterprise and
start the antimatter transfer.
T'POL: I'm sorry, Captain. I can't obey that order.
ARCHER: You may not be wearing a uniform, but you can still be charged
with insubordination.
T'POL: Perhaps we should contact Starfleet, and discuss this with
Admiral Forrest.
ARCHER: You're relieved as First Officer. Major, escort T'Pol back to
the ship and confine her to her quarters.
HAYES: Sir?
ARCHER: I gave you an order.
HAYES: Ma'am.
(A glance from the Captain sends the gobsmacked engineers scurrying
back to work.)
 [Archer's quarters]
 (Archer comes out of the bathroom, showered and
shaved, when the doorbell chimes.)
ARCHER: Come in.
TUCKER: The first shuttlepod's on it's way.
ARCHER: How long will it take to transfer the antimatter?
TUCKER: Using both shuttlepods, about four or five hours.
ARCHER: I didn't realise how badly I needed a shower. I've spent too
much time in that hatchery.
TUCKER: If you're looking for a new first officer, you should consider
Malcolm. You're going to want someone on the Bridge full time, and I'm
a little busy at the moment.
ARCHER: I'm happy with the command structure the way it is. This is
only temporary. T'Pol just needed a slap on the wrist.
TUCKER: She's questioned your orders lots of times, but you've never
locked her up before. You have to admit its a little out of the
ordinary.
ARCHER: These aren't ordinary circumstances. T'Pol refused a direct
order in front of the crew. I can't have senior officers behaving like
that, especially on a mission this important.
TUCKER: Maybe you ought to confine me to quarters too, sir, because I'm
still not sure we're doing the right thing here. If the roles were
reversed I can't imagine these Xindi would do the same for us.
ARCHER: My great grandfather was in North Africa during the Eugenics
Wars. His battalion was evacuating civilians from a war zone when they
came under attack. There was a school full of children directly between
them and the enemy. If his men had returned fire, they might have hit
it. So he called the commander on the other side, and got him to agree
to hold his fire long enough to evacuate the school. There are rules,
Trip, even in war. We have to help these children.
 [Armoury]
 (On the screen, an image of Enterprise chases an
image of an Insectoid ship.)
REED: This is what you wanted to show me, a battle simulation?
HAYES: Scenarios like this can tell us a lot about the enemy's tactical
capabilities. Much more that we'd learn from a standard analysis.
REED: I asked you to look for weaknesses in their shields, not to play
more games.
HAYES: This isn't exactly a game, Lieutenant. The simulation found that
they're vulnerable here. They've got minimal shielding around their
impulse manifolds. A pair of torpedoes should be enough to take out the
engines.
REED: Those manifolds are pretty narrow, but our targeting scanners
should be able to get a lock. Nice work.
HAYES: Thank you, sir.
REED: I apologise. I over-reacted. A lot of the crew's on edge lately.
HAYES: They certainly are.
REED: I heard things got pretty ugly down there.
HAYES: It's not every day I'm asked to confine a senior officer. I
can't say I disagree with the Captain's decision. If one of my men
disobeyed orders I'd throw him in the stockade.
REED: I've got to get back to the Bridge. Let me know if your
simulation finds anything else.
 [Outside T'Pol's quarters]
 TUCKER: I need to see T'Pol.
CHANG: She's not suppose to have any visitors, sir.
TUCKER: This isn't a social call. I'm here for my neuropressure
treatment. Doctor's orders. You don't want me to bring Phlox down here,
do you?
(Chang steps aside.)
 [T'Pol's quarters]
 T'POL: What's our status?
TUCKER: The antimatter's on it's way. I had a talk with him.
Everything's going to be all right. This whole thing'll blow over in a
day or two.
T'POL: Our antimatter supply will be depleted by then. The Captain's
behaviour is becoming increasingly illogical, even for a human. He's
preoccupied with the hatchery, he's displaying signs of paranoia.
TUCKER: I think you're overstating things just a little.
T'POL: You can't allow him to use our antimatter.
TUCKER: What do you suggest I do, start a mutiny?
T'POL: You have to speak with Phlox. Ask him to run a full exam on the
Captain.
TUCKER: What good would that do?
T'POL: If the Doctor can find something wrong, we may have medical
grounds to relieve him of command.
TUCKER: Relieve him? Look, I know you're upset about what happened, but
I think you're taking this personally.
T'POL: How long before the reactor's brought online?
TUCKER: Assuming Hoshi can translate the interface, about twelve hours.
T'POL: You have to delay it until we can verify the Captain's mental
state.
TUCKER: If he finds out what we're doing, we'll both end up in the
Brig. You're asking me to betray him.
T'POL: You can't allow your personal feelings for the Captain to affect
your decision. We both know he's endangering this ship and our mission.
 [Bridge]
 REED: What is it?
TRAVIS: A subspace vortex is opening off the port bow.
REED: Tactical alert. Captain Archer, report to the Bridge.
HOSHI: It's an insectoid, three biosigns aboard.
TRAVIS: They're firing. (Enterprise rocks to the impact.) TRAVIS: They're moving
away at full impulse.
REED: Pursuit course. Arm phase cannons. Disable their engines. (Two
phase shots are fired.)
TRAVIS: No effect.
HOSHI: Their main deflector's charging. They could be trying to open a
vortex.
REED: Torpedoes. Maximum yield. Target their impulse manifolds.
OFFICER: Ready.
REED: Fire.
(One torpedo misses, the other blows it to pieces just as Archer comes
on deck.)
ARCHER: What the hell's going on?
REED: An insectoid ship, sir.
ARCHER: You destroyed them?
REED: They were opening a vortex. They would have escaped.
ARCHER: The crew might have been able to take care of the hatchery.
REED: Sir?
ARCHER: We could have kept our antimatter and continued the mission.
REED: They would have told their superiors, sir. Given away our
position.
ARCHER: If you'd explained to them why we were here, you might have
avoided a fire fight.
REED: With all due respect sir, they didn't seem particularly
interested in talking.
ARCHER: Archer to Major Hayes.
HAYES [OC]: Go ahead, Captain.
ARCHER: Report to my Ready room, on the double.
HAYES [OC]: Aye, sir.
ARCHER: I'm relieving you as Tactical officer. From now on, you'll
report to Major Hayes.
REED: I did what was necessary to protect this ship and its mission.
ARCHER: You'll be confined to quarters until further notice.
REED: Captain.
ARCHER: Dismissed.
REED: Yes, sir. (Reed leaves.)
ARCHER: Are you done with that translation?
HOSHI: Almost.
ARCHER: I want you to put together a distress call in the Insectoid
language. Transmit it on all frequencies as soon as you're ready.
HOSHI: Understood.
 [Ready room]
 ARCHER: There's nothing more important than the
success of this mission. Do you agree, Major?
HAYES: Of course, sir.
ARCHER: My senior officers don't seem to understand what I'm trying to
do here. I guess I have myself to blame. In the past, I've encouraged
them to ask questions, but we don't have time for that now. I need
officers who respect the chain of command and can follow orders.
HAYES: It won't be a problem, sir.
ARCHER: I thought what happened with T'Pol might have been an isolated
incident, but I'm not so sure now. Lieutenant Reed destroyed a ship
that could have helped us. I'm starting to wonder if he deliberately
tried to sabotage this mission. You're in command while I'm on the
surface. You answer to me, and me alone. Is that understood, Major?
HAYES: Perfectly, sir.
ARCHER: That'll be all.
 [Launch bay]
 TUCKER: Can we talk to you for a minute, sir? (Archer is loading canisters into Shuttlepod One.)
ARCHER: What is it?
TUCKER: I'd like you to go to Sickbay with Phlox.
ARCHER: Do I look sick to you?
TUCKER: Hoshi says you ordered her to transmit a distress call.
ARCHER: That's right.
TUCKER: Don't you think that's a little dangerous?
ARCHER: We'll be light years from here before the Xindi respond to it.
TUCKER: We don't know how far away their ships are. If we send that
message we'll be taking a hell of a risk.
ARCHER: We can't afford to play it safe anymore. This mission's too
important.
TUCKER: This mission is to save Earth, not an alien hatchery.
PHLOX: Captain, you haven't eaten or slept in almost two days. You've
shown signs of obsessional behaviour and paranoia.
ARCHER: If it'll make the two of you feel better, I'll go to Sickbay
for a complete physical as soon as that reactor's online.
TUCKER: That's not good enough, sir. Phlox has the authority to order
you to Sickbay.
ARCHER: T'Pol's manipulating you, isn't she. If I'm declared unfit for
duty, then she takes over.
PHLOX: Captain, if you won't come with me then I'll be required under
Starfleet order 104 section C to relieve you of command.
ARCHER: I expected something like this from her, but not from the two
of you. Corporal. (A MACO comes from around the corner.) ARCHER: I've already
confined two senior officers today.
(As they leave, Phlox checks the medical scanner he had hidden in his
pocket.)
 [Sickbay]
 (Looking at the results of the scan on the
overhead monitor.)
PHLOX: His neurochemistry appears normal.
TUCKER: There's nothing wrong with him?
PHLOX: This scan is hardly conclusive. I'll need to get him into the
imaging chamber and run a complete neurological series.
TUCKER: When Hoshi sends that distress call, every Xindi ship that
picks it up will start heading this way. He's got Hayes on the Bridge,
MACOs posted all over the ship. Whatever we do, we're going to have to
do it fast.
PHLOX: What are you proposing, Commander?
TUCKER: I think it's time we throw the rule book out the window.
 [Hatchery]
 CREWMAN: Captain. (Some eggs are starting to
hatch.)
 [Outside T'Pol's quarters]
 (Tucker is clutching his shoulder and looking
uncomfortable.)
CHANG: I'm sorry sir, no visitors.
TUCKER: You let me in before.
CHANG: I have new orders from Major Hayes.
TUCKER: Look, T'Pol was a little rough with me during the last session.
I think she caused some nerve damage.
CHANG: You'll have to speak with the Major, sir.
(We see Reed and Phlox sneaking down the corridor while Chang is
distracted.)
TUCKER: This is a Starfleet ship. I don't have to ask Major Hayes for
anything.
CHANG: Step away, sir. (Reed is holding a phase pistol.)
REED: Stand down, Corporal. (Phlox injects
Chang.)
 [T'Pol's quarters]
 TUCKER: The Captain gave Hayes control of the
Bridge, posted MACOs on every deck.
T'POL: Is he still on the surface?
TUCKER: Yeah.
T'POL: Retrieving him and the antimatter should be the priority.
REED: I'd advise securing the Bridge first. If Hayes gets wind of this
we could have a fire-fight on our hands.
PHLOX: Perhaps we should approach the Major and explain the situation.
He seems like a reasonable man.
REED: That would be risky. If Hayes sides with the Captain, this mutiny
will be over before it begins.
T'POL: We'll need more people. Who's on duty in the Armoury?
REED: Ensign Walsh and two of my men. They'll side with us, but Hayes
posted two MACO there.
 [Hatchery]
 (Lots of the eggs are starting to jiggle.)
ARCHER: Take the shuttlepod back to Enterprise.
CREWMAN: What about you, sir?
ARCHER: You heard me.
(The two crewmen pick up the boxes and go.)
 [Armoury]
 (T'Pol comes down the steps in a Starfleet uniform
and baseball cap, then neck pinches one MACO.)
REED: Hold it. Sorry. (He stuns at other MACO.)
TUCKER: That's going to leave a bruise. (They all arm themselves.) TUCKER: All
right? You're with me.
WALSH: Yes, sir.
(Walsh and Tucker transport themselves into the crashed ship.)
 [Corridor]
 (Seeing two MACO by the turbolift.)
REED: Well, we won't get to the Bridge this way.
(The four head to an access ladder instead.)
 [Hatchery]
 (The hatch opens and Tucker throws in a stun
grenade to knock out the MACOs in the airlock before heading into the
main chamber.) TUCKER: Captain! (There are young Insectoids
running around the floor.) TUCKER: Captain, it's Trip!
ARCHER: You shouldn't have weapons in here.
 [Bridge]
 HAYES: Go ahead.
HAWKINGS [OC]: Major, Corporal Chang's been found unconscious in
T'Pol's quarters.
HAYES: Where's T'Pol?
HAWKINGS [OC]: Not here, sir.
HAYES: Hayes to the Armoury. Armoury, respond. (He nods to the MACO at
Tactical who leaves his post, then the Bridge doors open at the side
and in the Situation room. There's a standoff between the mutineers and
the MACOs, particularly Reed and Hayes with pistols aimed at each
other's heads.)
REED: Stand down!
HAYES: You intend to shoot me, Lieutenant?
REED: Tell them to stand down.
HAYES: The Captain relieved you of duty. Both of you.
T'POL: We don't want anyone injured. Put down your weapons.
HAYES: Until the Captain says otherwise, I give the orders on this
Bridge.
 [Hatchery]
 ARCHER: Go back to the ship.
TUCKER: You have to come with us. (An Insectoid leaves it's egg and
crawls over Archer.) TUCKER: Captain!
ARCHER: Shush. It's all right. (A second baby climbs onto him, and a
third. Tucker stuns him.)
 [Bridge]
 HAYES: Contact the Captain.
T'POL: Belay that.
HAYES: I gave you a direct order, Ensign.
HOSHI: I'm sorry, Major.
(Hayes starts to back up to open a comm. channel himself, and Travis
jumps him. One Starfleet and two MACOs get stunned. Reed holds a pistol to Hayes' head.)
REED: It's over, Major. Take him to his
quarters.
TRAVIS: Aye, sir.
HOSHI: It's Commander Tucker.
T'POL: Put him through. Go ahead.
TUCKER [OC]: We've got the Captain. What's going on up there?
T'POL: The Bridge is secure.
 [Hatchery]
 TUCKER: Tell Phlox to get the imaging chamber
ready. We've got a patient for him.T'POL [OC]: Acting Captain's starlog,
supplemental. We've resumed our course for Azati Prime. Major Hayes and
his men have been temporarily relieved of duty. Doctor Phlox believes
he has found an explanation for the Captain's behaviour.
 [Sickbay]
 HAYES: Where is he?
PHLOX: In his quarters, resting. Do you recall when the Captain was
attacked by one of the eggs?
HAYES: It sprayed something in his face.
PHLOX: I thought it was a defence reflex, but it was actually something
far more sophisticated. The substance contained a unique neurochemical.
It infiltrated the Captain's synaptic pathways, causing him to reverse
imprint on the baby insectoids. It's the opposite of what happens when
a young animal bonds with its mother.
HAYES: Are you saying he thought he was the mother of those things?
PHLOX: Well, more likely a caretaker. Of course, the Captain didn't
realise this on a conscious level. Eventually he became obsessed with
protecting the eggs to the exclusion of everything else.
T'POL: Including our mission.
HAYES: I'd like to speak with him, if you don't mind.
PHLOX: He'll be awake in a few hours. He should be fully recovered by
then.
T'POL: I want you and your men to return to duty.
HAYES: Yes, ma'am. (T'Pol and Trip leave.) HAYES: Not the sort of thing they
trained us for at West Point.
REED: I imagine not.
HAYES: You could have come to me, explained the situation.
REED: We couldn't take the chance that you'd side with the Captain.
HAYES: I probably would have.
REED: Yeah.
 [Archer's quarters]
 (The room is darkened, Archer is dozing with
Porthos by his side when the doorbell chimes.)
ARCHER: Come in.
TUCKER: I didn't mean to wake you, sir.
ARCHER: It's all right, I was getting up anyway.
TUCKER: How are you feeling?
ARCHER: Oh, I've been better. Are you sure you had that pistol set to
stun?
TUCKER: Captain. I hope you understand, if there'd been any other way
ARCHER: You were protecting our mission, Trip. I would have done the
same thing.
TUCKER: Still, I never thought I'd find myself pointing a weapon at
you, no matter what the circumstances.
ARCHER: Let's put this behind us, okay?
TUCKER: Yes, sir.
ARCHER: What's our status?
TUCKER: We just recovered the last of our antimatter reserves.
ARCHER: The hatchlings?
TUCKER: Phlox says there's nineteen of them running around down there.
Chances are they'll survive until the next Xindi ship comes along.
ARCHER: It's time we got back on the road. I want you at your post.
We're going to be pushing the engines pretty hard. I'll be on the
Bridge.
TUCKER: Aren't you supposed to get some rest?
ARCHER: I've had plenty.
TUCKER: I'm sorry, sir, but the Doctor was insistent.
ARCHER: Okay. I guess I don't want another mutiny on my hands. Tell
Travis to set a course for Azati Prime, maximum warp.
TUCKER: Right away, sir. 
<Back
to the episode listing
